content:
1- The governmental entity shall inform all competitors of the information related to the scope of work in the project; enabling them to assess the work before obtaining the tender documents, providing the necessary clarifications and data about the work and purchases required to be executed before the deadline for submitting bids with sufficient time, and the entity is committed to non-discrimination among competitors in any of the foregoing.
2- Without prejudice to the provisions of paragraph (1) of Article (twelve) of the system, it is prohibited for the employees of the governmental entity, consultants, and participants in preparing the tender documents from disclosing any information about the tender before it is floated.
3- The governmental entity must notify all tender applicants of any amendments made to it.
4- The governmental entity is not permitted to amend the terms, specifications, and quantities after the bids have been submitted, except in accordance with the provisions of the system and these bylaws, and the tender shall be cancelled in case of violation thereof.
summary: This article stipulates the transparency of the governmental entity in informing competitors of relevant project information, prohibiting disclosure of information before the tender is floated, notifying applicants of any amendments, and prohibiting amendment of terms after bids are submitted.

content: Securing works and purchases must be based on achieving the public interest and the actual need of the entity, and quality and economic efficiency must be taken into account in these works and purchases, and developmental aspects and approved strategic plans must be considered.
summary: This article emphasizes that securing works and purchases should be based on public interest and the entity's actual needs, while considering quality, economic efficiency, developmental aspects, and strategic plans.

content:
1- The entity shall publish its work and procurement plan –pursuant to paragraph (1) of Article (twelve) of the system– during the first quarter of each fiscal year, provided that the plan shall include at least the following information:
A- Type and nature of works and purchases.
B- Place of execution.
C- Method of tendering and contracting.
2- Works and purchases related to national security, weapons, and military equipment are excluded from publication.
3- Publication shall be on the portal and the governmental entity’s website, and shall continue until the works are floated.
4- Plan information shall be updated continuously.
summary: This article mandates the publication of the entity's work and procurement plan during the first quarter of each fiscal year, excluding national security related items, and publishing on the portal and the entity's website.

content:
1- Taking into account the provisions of paragraph (2) of Article (three) of the system, the following are required for contracting with unlicensed foreign persons in accordance with the provisions of the Foreign Investment System to execute works within the Kingdom:
A- Advertisement on the portal and the governmental entity’s website, to verify the absence of more than one qualified local person.
B- Obtaining a license from the Ministry of Investment.
C- Carrying out the necessary qualification in accordance with the provisions of the system and these bylaws.
D- Compliance with the provisions of the bylaw for prioritizing local content, small and medium-sized local enterprises, and companies listed on the financial market in works and purchases.
2- Securing works and purchases shall be in accordance with the contracting methods stipulated in the system and these bylaws.
summary: This article stipulates the requirements for contracting with unlicensed foreign individuals, including advertisement on the portal, obtaining a license from the Ministry of Investment, qualification, and compliance with the local content bylaw.

content:
Works and purchases executed outside the Kingdom are exempt from the following provisions:
1. (Article nine) of the system.
2. Paragraph (1) of Article fifteen of the system, except for framework agreements concluded by the entity responsible for unified procurement related to works and purchases whose provisions stipulate the possibility of their execution outside the Kingdom.
3. Article sixteen of the system, and paragraphs (1) and (4) of Article thirty-seven of the system, whereby governmental entities in government tenders and purchases may float all their procedures, including the receipt of bids, without using the portal and using any alternative means they deem appropriate, provided that this does not violate the governmental entity’s obligation to upload contracts after signing them to the portal.
4. Paragraph (1) of Article forty-one of the system, whereby the governmental entity may not require the submission of a preliminary guarantee as it deems in the best interest.
5. Paragraph (4) of Article (forty-five) of the system; whereby it is permissible to combine the chairmanship or membership of committees, taking into account that combining committees should be kept to a minimum.
6. Paragraph (1) of Article fifty-five of the system, whereby the governmental entity –as it deems in the best interest– may use any language other than Arabic in drafting the contracts and their documents and annexes, and specifying the language used to interpret and execute the contract, provided that the entity is committed to preparing an Arabic translation of any of those documents.
7. Paragraph (1) of Article sixty-one of the system, whereby the governmental entity may not require the submission of a final guarantee as it deems in the best interest, with the entity’s commitment to determining an alternative mechanism to guarantee the quality of project execution as much as practically possible, according to the procedure applied in the country of execution, and as it may deem appropriate to require the submission of a final guarantee, specifying the period it deems appropriate for its submission, provided that it is mentioned in the tender documents, and it may extend that period as it deems in the best interest.
8. From the commitment to the qualification document templates referred to in Article ninety-one of the system, and that the provisions thereof shall be followed as much as practically possible in line with the circumstances of the country of execution, and if it is not possible to follow the provisions thereof, the reasons and justifications shall be mentioned in the minutes of the project qualification committee.
summary: This article exempts works and purchases executed outside the Kingdom from several provisions of the system, including the use of the electronic portal, submission of guarantees, and contract language.

chapter.name: Works and Purchases Executed Outside the Kingdom

content:
Taking into account the provisions of Article (fourteen) of the system, the Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency shall undertake the following:
1- Preparing strategies for works and purchases, specifying the controls for contracting, purchasing, and quantities.
2- Preparing lists of works and purchases that are frequently requested to be secured by the governmental entity, and publishing them on the electronic portal.
3- Periodically monitoring data on purchases and contracts concluded by governmental entities.
summary: This article outlines the responsibilities of the Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency, including preparing strategies and lists, and monitoring purchases and contracts.

content:
1- The governmental entity shall submit to the Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency a feasibility study, estimated cost, tender documents, prior qualification documents –if any–, and the procedures it has taken in works and purchases whose estimated cost exceeds (twenty-five) million riyals, and the center may –with the approval of the minister– amend this amount.
2- The Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency shall review what the governmental entity submits pursuant to paragraph (1) of this article, and respond within a period not exceeding (fifteen) working days from the date of receipt.
summary: This article mandates the governmental entity to submit feasibility studies and estimated costs exceeding 25 million riyals to the Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency, who must review and respond within 15 working days.

content:
Firstly: Without prejudice to the confidentiality required by national security; the electronic portal –referred to in Article (sixteen) of the system– provides information related to the government tenders and purchases system, including:
1- The government tenders and purchases system and its executive bylaws, decisions, and circulars issued for the purpose of applying the system.
2- Regulations related to the system, including the bylaw for prioritizing local content, small and medium-sized enterprises, and companies listed on the financial market in works and purchases, and other economic development goals.
3- Policies, guidelines, instructions, and guidance and training manuals related to implementing the system and these bylaws.
4- Strategies and initiatives implemented to enhance efficiency in government purchases.
5- Annual work and purchases plans for governmental entities.
6- Information on framework agreements available for use by governmental entities.
7- Data on previous procurement procedures carried out by governmental entities, and procedures planned to be carried out or under execution, provided that they are updated and include the progress of these procedures.
8- Advertisements and other notices that must be published pursuant to the system and these bylaws.
9- Templates of tender documents, qualification documents, and contract templates related to the works and purchases of governmental entities.
10- Minutes of bid opening committees and reports on tender procedures at governmental entities.
11- Decisions on complaints, violations, and grievances issued by the review committees referred to in Article (eighty-six) and Article (eighty-eight) of the system.
12- Annual reports or other reports related to the government tenders and purchases system.
Secondly: The government tenders and purchases procedures referred to in Article (sixteen) of the system include all operations related to implementing the government purchases cycle, and access to and execution thereof are available through the portal, and include:
1- Registering suppliers, contractors, and undertakers on the portal, and managing their data.
2- Creating purchase and need requests.
3- Carrying out qualification processes.
4- Advertising on the portal, and submitting price quotation requests.
5- Receiving inquiries from competitors, and responding to them.
6- Amending tender documents.
7- Receiving, opening, and examining bids.
8- Postponing the opening of technical bids and extending their receipt.
9- Extending the validity of bids.
10- Notification of award.
11- Cancellation of the tender.
12- Completing the tender and contracting procedures.
13- Publishing summaries of the decisions of the committee referred to in Article (eighty-eight) of the system.
14- Informing competitors of any procedure that requires it.
Thirdly: The technical reasons referred to in Article (sixteen) of the system mean the technical malfunctions that affect the portal and prevent governmental entities or competitors from using it and completing their assigned tasks for a period exceeding (three) consecutive days, in accordance with what the portal’s rules and procedures clarify.
Fouthly: In the event of a technical malfunction in the portal, the procedure that cannot be executed shall be extended for a period equal to the duration of the malfunction. If the malfunction continues for a period exceeding the period mentioned in paragraph (Thirdly) of this article, it must be executed in paper form, provided that the entity uploads the procedures that have been carried out to the portal immediately after the malfunction ceases.
summary: This article explains the information and services provided by the electronic portal, the procedures for tenders and purchases through it, the definition of technical reasons for malfunctions, and the procedures followed in the event of a malfunction.

content:
Taking into account the provisions of Article (seventeen) of the system:
1- The electronic portal must include the necessary instructions for its use and how to implement the procedures for floating works and purchases.
2- The portal must enable governmental entities and competitors to carry out all operations and requests related to government tenders and purchases, in accordance with the provisions of the system and these bylaws.
3- The portal must provide what guarantees the confidentiality of the data received from users and the bids submitted by competitors, so that access thereto is prohibited except in accordance with the provisions of the system and these bylaws.
4- Except for the estimated cost of the project; the governmental entity shall publish the tender documents –including the general and special conditions and bill of quantities– and the costs of the tender documents on the electronic portal.
5- The governmental entity shall inform all competitors of the inquiries it receives regarding the floated tender and their answers without disclosing the identity of the competitor submitting the inquiry.
6- The portal provides the necessary reports to those with authority and supervisory bodies responsible for monitoring and reviewing purchasing operations and contract execution. It also provides statistics and data on government tenders and purchases, especially the amount of spending in the governmental entity and the rates of participation of suppliers, contractors, or undertakers, without prejudice to the requirements of confidentiality in accordance with the provisions of the system and these bylaws.
7- Works and purchases related to national security, weapons, and military equipment are excluded from being kept in the records of governmental entities on the portal, and the governmental entity may suffice with keeping the records related to those purchases with it. The portal must also include records of user operations, and data and information of contractors with the governmental entity so that other governmental entities can access them for the purpose of implementing their projects.
summary: This article explains the requirements of the electronic portal, including instructions, data confidentiality, and providing reports and statistics, with an exception for national security related purchases.

content:
The portal shall publish a list of contractors, suppliers, and undertakers prohibited from dealing with the government, provided that the list shall include the following:
1- Name and address of the establishment.
2- Commercial register number or system license.
3- Reason for the prohibition from dealing.
4- Number and date of the prohibition decision or judicial ruling.
5- Duration of the prohibition from dealing and its expiry date.
summary: This article mandates the publication of a list of prohibited contractors, suppliers, and undertakers on the portal, with details of each prohibition.

content: The ministry shall be responsible for responding to inquiries and questions related to the use of the portal; with regard to the systematic and technical aspects, by providing a communication channel between the beneficiary entities using the portal in accordance with the provisions of the system and these bylaws.
summary: This article assigns the ministry the responsibility of responding to inquiries and questions related to the use of the portal, both systematically and technically.

content: The ministry shall issue rules and procedures for using the portal.
summary: This article empowers the ministry to issue rules and procedures for using the electronic portal.

content:
1- Those wishing to deal with governmental entities to execute their purchases and works –pursuant to the system and these bylaws– must have the following documents:
A- Commercial register, or system licenses in the field of the works applied for, if the competitor is not required by law to be registered in the commercial register.
B- Zakat or tax payment certificate, or both, if the competitor is required by law to pay Zakat and tax.
C- A certificate from the General Organization for Social Insurance certifying the registration of the establishment in the organization and the payment of insurance dues.
D- Certificate of membership in the chamber of commerce, if the competitor is required by law to be a member of the chamber.
E- Classification certificate in the field of works applied for, if those works are subject to classification.
F- Certificate of membership in the Saudi Council of Engineers, if the works applied for are engineering works.
G- Certificate of membership in the Saudi Contractors Authority, if the works applied for are related to construction and contracting.
H- Proof that the establishment is among the small and medium-sized local establishments, if the establishment belongs to that category, as determined by the General Authority for Small and Medium Enterprises.
I- Certificate of achieving the required percentage for job localization.
J- Any other documents requested by the governmental entity according to the nature of the project.
2- The documents referred to in paragraph (1) of this article must be valid upon bid opening.
3- Dealing with non-profit civil institutions or associations requires that they have a registration certificate proving that they are a civil institution or association or a non-profit entity from the competent authority.
4- Works and purchases executed outside the Kingdom by foreign persons are exempt from providing the documents referred to in paragraph (1) of this article, except for the documents in sub-paragraphs (A) and (J).
summary: This article specifies the documents required for dealing with governmental entities, with exemptions for works executed outside the Kingdom.

chapter.name: Conditions for Dealing with Governmental Entities

content:
Firstly: Neither the governmental entity nor its contractor –with regard to the works contracted with the governmental entity and at any stage of the contract– may deal in accordance with the provisions of the system and these bylaws with the persons referred to below:
1- Government employees, except for the following:
A- Non-commercial work if they are licensed to practice it.
B- Purchasing their publications or any intellectual property rights, whether directly from them or through publishing houses or others.
C- Commissioning them for artistic works.
D- Entering public auctions, if the items desired to be purchased are for their personal use.
2- Those whose dealings are prohibited by the systems, including those who have been prohibited from dealing with by a judicial ruling or a decision from an entity authorized to do so by law, until the period of prohibition ends.
3- Bankrupts, or those who are proven insolvent, or those who have been ordered to be placed under judicial custody.
4- Companies that have been dissolved or liquidated.
5- Those who have not reached the age of (eighteen) years.
6- Those with limited capacity.
Secondly: Without prejudice to the provisions of paragraph (1/b) of Article (seventy-six) of the system; those who have not had one or more liquidation proceedings opened against them in accordance with the provisions of the Bankruptcy System shall not be considered bankrupt –in application of the provisions of the system–.
summary: This article prohibits dealing with specific categories of individuals, including government employees (with exceptions), those prohibited from dealing by law, bankrupts, and dissolved companies.

chapter.name: Conditions for Dealing with Governmental Entities

content:
1- The governmental entity may carry out prior qualification in major or complex projects, or those with high costs whose estimated cost exceeds (fifty) million riyals, for the purpose of identifying qualified competitors before inviting them to submit bids.
2- The governmental entity must carry out subsequent qualification in works and purchases for which prior qualification has not been carried out.
3- If the governmental entity has previously qualified a competitor, it may not qualify that competitor in similar works and purchases, provided that more than one year has not passed since the previous qualification.
4- The competition method and the direct purchase method in cases of executing works and purchases whose estimated cost does not exceed (one hundred thousand) riyals or emergency cases are exempt from the provisions of paragraphs (1) and (2) of this article.
summary: This article stipulates prior qualification for major projects, subsequent qualification if no prior qualification exists, with exemptions for competition and direct purchase methods.

content:
1- Taking into account the provisions of paragraph (1/a) of Article (nineteen) of these bylaws, the governmental entity must carry out subsequent qualification for the winning bidder who was previously qualified for it with prior qualification, if the period between the prior qualification and the award exceeds (one) year; to ensure the continuation of his qualifications.
2- If the winning bidder does not pass the subsequent qualification stage, the next bidder in order shall be chosen, and so on, and the tender shall be cancelled if none of the competitors pass it.
3- When carrying out subsequent qualification for the winning bidder, the governmental entity must apply the same criteria applied in the prior qualification stage.
summary: This article mandates subsequent qualification for the winning bidder if more than one year has passed since prior qualification, specifying procedures if the bidder fails.

content:
Taking into account the provisions of Article (twenty) of the system:
1- The governmental entity must apply the criteria, conditions, and mechanism stipulated in the qualification documents prepared by the Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency.
2- The following shall be taken into account when setting the criteria for prior or subsequent qualification:
A- Financial capabilities.
B- Administrative capabilities.
C- Technical capabilities.
D- The volume of existing contractual obligations, and the volume of completed projects.
E- Experience.
F- The size, nature, and estimated cost of the project.
G- Results of previous evaluations.
3- Prior qualification documents are available electronically through the portal.
4- Qualification criteria must be clear, objective, and in the public interest, and must not aim to restrict dealings to specific competitors.
summary: This article mandates the application of qualification criteria from the Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency, considering financial, administrative, and technical aspects, and ensuring criteria clarity and objectivity.

content:
Prior qualification shall be announced in accordance with the mechanism followed in announcing the tender, and the announcement must include –at a minimum– the following data:
1- Name of the governmental entity.
2- Type and nature of the project and its place of execution.
3- Qualification criteria and procedures.
4- Deadline for submitting qualification documents.
5- Deadline for announcing qualified parties.
summary: This article details the information to be included in the announcement of prior qualification, including the entity's name, project type, criteria, procedures, and deadlines.

content:
1- When carrying out prior qualification, the entity shall take into account the following:
A- If only one competitor applies for or passes the prior qualification, the governmental entity shall review the qualification criteria and repeat the prior qualification, or cancel the prior qualification and switch to subsequent qualification.
B- Informing the applicant for qualification of the result of his qualification, including the reasons for his exclusion in the event of failing to pass the qualification.
2- Those who have passed the prior qualification shall be invited to complete the tender procedures in accordance with the provisions of the system and these bylaws.
summary: This article outlines procedures for reviewing qualification criteria if only one competitor applies, informing applicants of results, and inviting those who passed.

content:
The head of the governmental entity –or his delegate– shall issue a decision to form one or more committees to carry out the prior and subsequent qualification procedures, in accordance with the following controls:
1- The number of committee members shall not be less than three in addition to its chairman, provided that at least one of them shall be from those with technical knowledge of the nature of the works and purchases subject to the tender.
2- Care shall be taken not to combine membership or chairmanship of this committee with any of the other committees in the system and these bylaws. Works and purchases carried out outside the Kingdom are excepted from this.
3- The formation decision shall stipulate the appointment of a vice-chairman who shall replace the chairman in his absence.
4- The committee shall be reconstituted every three years.
summary: This article mandates the formation of a qualification committee of at least three members, with considerations for avoiding conflicts of interest, appointing a vice-chairman, and reconstituting the committee every three years.

content:
Tender documents must include the full details of the works and purchases offered, including the following:
1- Instructions and conditions of the tender.
2- Terms and specifications of the works and purchases.
3- Tables and items of quantities or service provision criteria.
4- Criteria and percentages for evaluating bids.
5- Classification field, if any.
6- Plans and drawings as the case may be.
7- Place, time, and mechanism for submitting samples –if required–, their fate after examination, and the mechanism for their recovery.
8- The text of the contract to be concluded, its terms and conditions, including payment methods and the mechanism for calculating penalties.
9- Terms and conditions of local content, if any.
10- Preliminary and final guarantees.
11- Terms and conditions of the framework agreement, if any.
12- Period of suspension for considering the objection to the award decision, and this does not include works and purchases executed using the direct purchase or competition methods.
13- Any other documents according to the nature of the works and purchases.
summary: This article specifies the contents of tender documents, including instructions, terms, specifications, quantities, evaluation criteria, and the contract text.

content:
1- The governmental entity shall provide sufficient paper copies of the tender documents in the event that it is not possible to obtain electronic copies for the technical reasons referred to in paragraph (Thirdly) of Article (eight) of these bylaws, and it is not permitted to refrain from providing them except for a legal justification.
2- All electronic copies shall be numbered.
summary: This article mandates the provision of paper copies of tender documents if electronic copies are unavailable, and the numbering of electronic copies.

content:
1- The governmental entity shall ensure accuracy in determining the costs of tender documents so that they reflect only the costs of their preparation, and avoid exaggeration in their value so as to discourage those wishing to apply for the tender.
2- The costs of preparing tender documents referred to in paragraph (1) of this article do not include the artistic and consulting work related to these documents.
summary: This article emphasizes accuracy in determining tender document costs, avoiding exaggeration, and not including artistic and consultancy work in those costs.

content:
Taking into account the provisions of Article (twenty-two) of the system, the governmental entity shall, when setting the terms and specifications, adhere to the following:
1- Not referring to the type, description, item, or number contained in the suppliers’ lists.
2- Not specifying specific trademarks or specifications that only apply to a specific product.
3- Not contracting for works whose quantities, categories, or specifications are not specified in the contract, unless stipulated in the system or these bylaws.
summary: This article specifies the controls for setting terms and specifications, including not referring to specific supplier lists or trademarks, and contracting for works with specified quantities.

content:
Regarding contractual and financial obligations, the following must be adhered to:
1- It is not permissible to contract for works and purchases unless the costs or financial appropriations are available, and the entity must take into account the annual cash flows of contracts in accordance with budget planning activities, including the items that are linked to.
2- The governmental entity, when there is an urgent need to save time in implementing tender procedures; may float that tender or invite bids before obtaining the necessary financial appropriations for the works and purchases, provided that the governmental entity mentions in the tender documents that the award and signing of the contract shall not be carried out except after the availability of financial appropriations or costs for the works or purchases.
3- Contracts concluded must include clear conditions for the annual cash flows committed to in contracts that extend for more than one fiscal year.
4- The governmental entity must stipulate in the award decision notified to the winning bidder that the governmental entity shall not be subject to any legal or financial obligation except after the contract is signed by all parties.
summary: This article mandates the availability of costs and financial appropriations before contracting, considering cash flows, with the possibility of floating the tender before appropriations are available in urgent cases.

content: The governmental entity shall update the information on its projects and works before their approval, and review the technical specifications, drawings, and plans and make any amendments or corrections thereto before floating its works in a public tender or securing its purchases; especially those documents that have been prepared for a long period or specifications of devices and programs that are constantly being updated.
summary: This article emphasizes the need to update project information and specifications before floating them, reviewing drawings and plans, especially for older documents or devices and programs that are constantly updated.

content:
1- Taking into account the provisions of Article (twenty-three) of the system, the governmental entity shall set indicative estimated prices for the works in the tables of items and quantities specific to the tender; with the assistance of the technical unit that participated in preparing the specifications and other pricing specialist entities, and the following must be taken into account –when setting prices–:
A- The prevailing prices in the market.
B- The prices previously dealt with.
C- The price references adopted internally and externally.
D- Price data issued by specialized entities, if any.
E- The estimated costs of works and purchases prepared by the Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency in accordance with the data and references contained in this article.
F- That the prices reflect the actual value of the works and purchases offered.
G- That the estimated prices be placed in an encrypted electronic file sent to the chairman of the bid examination committee before announcing the tender.
2- The governmental entity, the Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency, and all participants in setting the estimated prices shall maintain their confidentiality.
3- The tender shall be cancelled if the governmental entity does not set estimated prices.
summary: This article mandates setting indicative estimated prices for works, considering market prices and references, maintaining confidentiality, and cancelling the tender if estimated prices are not set.

content:
1- The Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency shall prepare controls for preparing bid evaluation criteria for different spending categories, and shall divide the points for evaluating price and non-price bids.
2- The governmental entity must adhere to preparing the criteria when preparing the tender document and tender documents in accordance with the controls referred to in paragraph (1) of this article, especially in the criteria for evaluating bids.
3- Taking into account Articles (twenty-four) and (twenty-five) of the system; the tender documents must include the evaluation criteria to be used and the mechanism for their application.
summary: This article tasks the Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency with preparing bid evaluation criteria, mandating the governmental entity's adherence to these criteria in tender documents.

content:
Taking into account the provisions of Article (twenty-four) of the system, and the provisions of the bylaw for prioritizing local content, small and medium-sized enterprises, and companies listed on the financial market in works and purchases, the bid evaluation criteria shall be clear, objective, and in the public interest, and shall not aim to award works to specific competitors, provided that the following shall be taken into account when preparing them:
1- That in works that do not require high or complex technical capabilities, the evaluation of the technical bid shall be based on whether it passes or not, and the winning bid shall be the lowest price.
2- That the highest percentage of weights in consultancy services that require high technical capabilities shall be for technical criteria.
summary: This article emphasizes that bid evaluation criteria should be clear and objective, considering technical capabilities in consultancy services, and that the lowest price bid should win in simple works.

content:
Taking into account the provisions of Article (twenty-six) of the system, the following are required for dividing the tender:
1- That the aim of dividing the tender shall not be to switch to other purchasing methods.
2- Including the tender division method, the items to be divided, and the mechanism for their award in the tender documents.
3- That the nature of the works and purchases is actually divisible in terms of value, duration, items, and elements.
4- If the interest requires dividing similar items; the approval of the Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency must be obtained before floating the tender.
5- That dividing the tender shall be in the public interest.
summary: This article specifies the conditions for dividing a tender, including not changing the purchasing method, including the division method in tender documents, and obtaining approval from the Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency.

content:
Firstly: The following are required for the solidarity among competitors to execute one project or several projects:
1- That solidarity is achieved before submitting the bid pursuant to an agreement concluded between the parties to the solidarity and certified by the chamber of commerce or the entities authorized for authentication, and the competitors –who are intended to be in solidarity– may submit with their bid a letter whereby they undertake to enter into a solidarity agreement if they are notified of the award of the tender to them.
2- That the agreement or letter of undertaking specifies the leader of the solidarity as the legal representative before the governmental entity; to complete the contracting procedures and sign the contract and for correspondence and communications.
3- That the agreement or letter of undertaking clarifies the work that each party to the solidarity shall undertake.
4- That the agreement or letter of undertaking stipulates the commitment and responsibility of the parties in solidarity jointly or individually for executing all the works offered in the tender.
5- That the bid and all its documents and supporting documents are signed by all parties to the solidarity.
6- That the solidarity agreement is submitted with the bid and all its documents and supporting documents.
7- No party to the solidarity may submit a bid individually or in solidarity with another competitor.
8- The solidarity agreement may not be amended after submission except with the approval of the governmental entity.
9- Taking into account the provisions of the Contractors Classification System, if the solidarity is between contractors.
Secondly: Unless the solidarity procedures require otherwise, the tender documents must show the qualification criteria on the basis of which all parties to the solidarity shall be evaluated, which each competitor in the solidarity must meet.
Thirdly: The governmental entity shall exclude the bid submitted by the parties in solidarity in the event of the withdrawal of one of them or his breach of the tender conditions or the provisions of the system and these bylaws, unless the other party to the solidarity is qualified to carry out those works individually after obtaining his written consent.
summary: This article specifies the conditions for competitor solidarity, including a certified solidarity agreement, specifying a leader, the responsibility of the parties, and excluding the bid if one party withdraws.

content:
The governmental entity may execute its works and purchases –in accordance with the provisions of the system and these bylaws– using one of the following methods:
1- Public tender.
2- Limited tender.
3- Two-stage tender.
4- Direct purchase.
5- Framework agreement.
6- Electronic reverse auction.
7- Industry localization and knowledge transfer.
8- Competition.
summary: This article lists the contract methods available to the governmental entity.

content:
The governmental entity shall announce the public tender in accordance with the following procedures:
1- All public tenders shall be announced on the portal, provided that the announcement shall continue until the final deadline for submitting bids. In addition to the announcement on the portal, the governmental entity may announce on its website, the official gazette, or any other means it deems appropriate.
2- Announcement shall be made outside the Kingdom for works and purchases carried out abroad and those for which there is not more than one undertaker or contractor within the Kingdom, in addition to announcing them inside the Kingdom in accordance with what is mentioned in paragraph (1) of this article.
3- The announcement outside the Kingdom shall be on advertising websites in the country where the works and purchases are to be executed, and on the website of the Kingdom’s embassy, if any. The governmental entity may add any other means it deems appropriate to those means; provided that the announcement is in Arabic and English and the language of the country in which the announcement is made and any other language the governmental entity deems appropriate.
4- The public tender announcement must include at least the following data:
A- Name of the announcing entity.
B- Tender number, description, and purpose.
C- Classification field, if any.
D- Costs of tender documents and place of payment.
E- Final deadline for receiving bids, and bid opening date.
5- If it is not possible to publish the public tender announcement on the portal for technical reasons, it shall be announced in the official gazette and its website, and the website of the entity in charge of the project, provided that the entity publishes the announcement on the portal when it resumes work, unless the deadline for receiving bids has ended.
summary: This article specifies the procedures for announcing a public tender, including publication on the portal, the entity's website, and the official gazette, with other means, and specifying announcement details.

content:
1- The period from the date of publishing the announcement on the portal until the final deadline for submitting bids must not be less than the following:
A- (Fifteen) days for works and purchases whose estimated cost is (five million) riyals or less.
B- (Thirty) days for works and purchases whose estimated cost is more than (five million) riyals and less than (one hundred million) riyals.
C- (Sixty) days for works and purchases whose estimated cost is (one hundred million) riyals or more.
2- The governmental entity may –after obtaining the minister’s approval– reduce the periods mentioned in this article, if the nature of the works and purchases does not require the full period to be met.
summary: This article specifies the minimum bid submission periods in a public tender, based on estimated cost, with the possibility of reducing the period with the minister's approval.

content: The governmental entity shall float works of services with continuous execution before the expiry of the existing contract by not less than one year.
summary: This article mandates floating continuous execution service works at least one year before the existing contract expires.

content:
When contracting using the limited tender method for works and purchases that are only available to a limited number of contractors, suppliers, or undertakers, the governmental entity must adhere to the following controls:
1- An announcement shall be published on the portal and the entity’s website; to ensure that there are no other contractors or suppliers in the field of the required works and purchases, provided that the announcement period shall not be less than (twenty) days from its publication date.
2- If the announcement or the lists referred to in paragraph (3) of this article show that there are more than five suppliers, contractors, or undertakers, the works and purchases shall be floated in a public tender.
3- The governmental entity shall prepare a list of works and purchases that are only available to a limited number of contractors, suppliers, and undertakers, and a list of the names of service providers for those works and purchases, and it shall be updated annually, provided that the public has access to it through the portal.
summary: This article specifies the controls for a limited tender, including publishing an announcement to ensure no other suppliers exist, switching to a public tender if more than five suppliers exist, and updating a supplier list.

content: When contracting using the limited tender method for works and purchases whose estimated value is (five hundred thousand) riyals or less, and the prices of the bids submitted exceed (five hundred thousand) riyals, and the lowest bid or the next in order does not agree to reduce its bid to reach this amount, the limited tender shall be cancelled and floated in a public tender.
summary: This article stipulates cancelling a limited tender and switching to a public tender if bid prices exceed 500,000 riyals and the lowest bid does not agree to a reduction.

content:
When contracting using the limited tender method for urgent works and purchases, the governmental entity must adhere to the following controls:
1- That the contracted works shall not be works that can be planned in advance.
2- What results from the governmental entity’s slowness in executing works and purchases shall not be considered among urgent cases.
3- The governmental entity shall assess urgent cases that cannot tolerate the procedures of a public tender, taking into account the interest of the facility, the execution circumstances, and the quantity and type of works and purchases required to be secured.
4- Works with continuous execution such as maintenance, cleaning, operation, and catering and transportation contracts, and works that are frequently secured periodically, and public construction works that are prepared for and their terms, specifications, and plans are set before their execution shall not be considered among urgent cases that may be secured by a limited tender.
summary: This article specifies the controls for a limited tender in urgent cases, excluding works that can be planned in advance, and works with continuous execution.

content:
When contracting using the limited tender method with civil institutions or associations or non-profit entities, the governmental entity must adhere to the following:
1- That there shall be more than one non-profit entity providing the required works and purchases.
2- That the works applied for shall be within its activity for which it was established.
3- That it executes the works itself.
4- The governmental entity shall prepare a list of non-profit entities that provide specific services in the field of the governmental entity’s activity, and the public has access to it through the portal.
summary: This article specifies the conditions for a limited tender with non-profit entities, including the existence of more than one entity, the works being within their activity, and providing a list of entities.

content:
Securing consultancy services shall be in accordance with the provisions of the limited tender as follows:
1- The governmental entity shall set the terms and specifications for consultancy services, and shall include at a minimum the following:
A- A general description of the nature of the required services and works.
B- The objectives to be achieved from consultancy services.
C- The scope of consultancy services and tasks that the consultant must perform.
D- The outputs to be delivered, including the results, reports, and executed works.
E- Knowledge, experience, and training transfer, if any.
F- Evaluation criteria.
2- The governmental entity shall prepare lists of consultancy firms on the portal for use when issuing invitations, provided that the number of those invited to submit their bids shall not be less than (five) consultancy firms.
3- When preparing the lists referred to in paragraph (2) of this article, the governmental entity shall publish an announcement on the electronic portal that includes a request for consultancy firms to express their desire to be included in the lists, and the announcement must include that the entity will issue invitations to a limited number of competitors listed in the lists who have been able to meet the qualification criteria specified in the announcement in order to submit their bids.
4- The governmental entity may use the direct purchase method to secure consultancy services if the conditions for direct purchase stipulated in Article (thirty-two) of the system are met.
summary: This article specifies the conditions for securing consultancy services through a limited tender, including setting terms and specifications, preparing lists of consultancy firms, and the possibility of using direct purchase.

content:
Taking into account the provisions of Article (thirty) of the system, the governmental entity shall, when executing works and purchases through a limited tender, adhere to the following:
1- Providing an opportunity for the largest possible number of competitors; so that the governmental entity’s dealings are not limited to a specific number of them, and keeping lists of those wishing to register to provide their services in various works and purchases, and publishing a continuous announcement on the portal for registration on those lists.
2- The announcement referred to in paragraph (1) of this article must include the following:
A- A description of the works, purchases, or services, and specifying their categories that can be used in those lists.
B- The conditions that those wishing to register must meet to be included in those lists, and the criteria by which the governmental entity verifies those conditions.
C- The name and address of the governmental entity that keeps the lists and its contact details, and the mechanism for obtaining the documents related to those lists.
D- The validity period of the lists and the mechanism for their renewal or cancellation, and if the validity period is not specified; the mechanism for notifying the registrants that those lists will no longer be used shall be indicated.
3- The governmental entity shall prepare on the portal a record of the works and purchases that have been executed through a limited tender as urgent cases.
4- The governmental entity must enable those wishing to register to apply at any time to register on the lists for various works, purchases, and services, and it must include all those qualified among them within a short period.
5- The governmental entity shall immediately notify its decision regarding the application of any of those wishing to register who have submitted applications to be included in the lists, or in the event of removing any of them from those lists for not meeting the registration conditions; stating the reasons for the decision in writing.
And for matters not specifically addressed, all provisions of the public tender shall apply to the limited tender.
summary: This article specifies the requirements for a limited tender, including providing an opportunity for the largest possible number of competitors, maintaining registration lists, publishing a continuous announcement, and notifying registration decisions.

content:
Taking into account the provisions of Article (thirty-one) of the system, the two-stage tender shall be carried out as follows:
Firstly: First stage:
1- The tender documents shall specify the governmental entity’s need and the purpose of the contract, the expected performance, and the qualifications required to accomplish the works and general information related to the terms, specifications, and other technical characteristics, whether for the works to be executed or the equipment and goods to be obtained.
2- The first stage shall be announced on the portal in accordance with the procedures for announcing the public tender.
3- Preliminary bids shall be submitted in the first stage that include the applicants’ proposals without mentioning the bid prices.
4- In addition to what is mentioned in paragraph (3) of this article, the governmental entity may request –without obligating them to do so– that competitors submit indicative or price limit prices for the works to be executed, provided that they are not obligated in the second stage to amend their bids to conform to what they submitted as indicative prices and price limits, or that their bids are evaluated on the basis thereof.
5- The governmental entity may discuss with the bidders to clarify what is mentioned in the bids and proposed specifications and make the necessary changes to the specifications to be acceptable and practically possible, provided that those inquiries and clarifications are published on the portal and are available for all bidders to view.
6- Bids that pass the first stage shall be announced on the electronic portal.
Secondly: Second stage:
After the end of the first stage, the governmental entity shall do the following:
1- Prepare and amend the technical specifications and prepare the tender documents and evaluation criteria, based on what has been reached during the first stage.
2- Send invitations to the successful bidders to submit their bids.
summary: This article explains the two-stage tender, detailing the procedures for each stage, including submitting preliminary bids without prices, then preparing the final tender documents.

content: Unless otherwise stipulated, the provisions and procedures of the public tender shall apply to the two-stage tender.
summary: This article stipulates that the provisions and procedures of the public tender apply to the two-stage tender unless otherwise stated.

content:
If the governmental entity wishes to secure works and purchases that are only available from one undertaker, contractor, or supplier, it shall take into account the following:
1- That there shall be a necessary need to secure the works and purchases, and that there shall be no suitable alternative that can be obtained from other sources.
2- That an announcement shall be published on the portal and the entity’s website, for a period of not less than (ten) working days; to ensure that the works and purchases are only available from one undertaker, contractor, or supplier. The governmental entity shall also verify this through other official sources, databases, and information available from other entities.
summary: This article specifies the conditions for direct purchase in the absence of alternatives, including a necessary need, and publishing an announcement to ensure no other suppliers exist.

content: Taking into account the provisions of paragraph (5) of Article (thirty-two) of the system, the governmental entity may contract directly with one civil institution or association or one entity from among the non-profit entities that is the only one providing the required works and purchases, provided that the works provided are within its activity.
summary: This article permits direct purchase from one civil institution or non-profit entity if no alternatives exist.

content:
The following are required for executing works and purchases in emergency cases:
1- The existence of one of the following cases:
A- A serious and unexpected threat to public safety, public health, or public security.
B- The existence of a serious event that threatens loss of life or property.
2- That using the procedures of a public tender or a limited tender would result in serious damage due to the length of the procedures.
3- That the framework agreement does not cover the required works and purchases or its execution is stalled.
4- Obtaining the approval of the head of the governmental entity.
5- Providing the General Auditing Bureau with all agreements, contracts, and disbursement documents related to those works and purchases.
summary: This article specifies the conditions for executing works and purchases in emergency cases, including a threat to public safety, lengthy procedures, and the head of the entity's approval.

content:
1- A committee or more of three members, whose chairman shall be appointed from among them, shall be formed by decision of the head of the governmental entity or his delegate, to examine direct purchase bids and submit recommendations to the authorized person.
2- Combining the chairmanship or membership of a direct purchase bid examination committee with the chairmanship or membership of any other committee formed in accordance with the provisions of the system and these bylaws is prohibited; except for works and purchases carried out outside the Kingdom.
3- Except for additional works; works and purchases amounting to (thirty) thousand riyals or less are exempted from being submitted to a direct purchase bid examination committee.
4- The authorized person shall decide on the works and purchases referred to in paragraph (3) of this article.
summary: This article mandates forming a committee to examine direct purchase bids, with exemptions for works less than 30,000 riyals.

content:
1- The governmental entity shall provide an opportunity in direct purchase for the largest possible number of dealers; so that its dealings are not limited to a specific number of them or that it constantly deals with specific companies or institutions. The entity is also committed to keeping lists of those wishing from institutions and companies to register to provide their services in various works and purchases, provided that those lists are announced continuously and registration is available through the portal.
2- Without prejudice to the confidentiality required by national security, the portal shall publish at the end of the fiscal year a list of direct purchase operations that have been executed in terms of the total value and type of works and purchases.
3- Without prejudice to the provisions of the direct purchase method; when using this method, the governmental entity may issue an invitation to one or more persons, or publish an announcement on the portal for a period determined by the entity, before contracting using this method, except for what is mentioned in paragraphs (1) and (4) of Article (thirty-two) of the system, and paragraph (2) of Article (forty-four) of these bylaws.
summary: This article emphasizes providing an opportunity for the largest possible number of dealers in direct purchase, and the possibility of issuing an invitation or publishing an announcement before contracting.

content:
Taking into account the provisions of Article (thirty-three) of the system, the governmental entity may contract through framework agreements in the following cases:
1- If there is a recurring need to contract to obtain goods, works, or services.
2- If it is expected in the future that there will be a need to purchase goods and services; due to the nature of the required goods and services.
3- If there is a need to deal with emergency cases.
summary: This article specifies the cases in which the governmental entity may contract through framework agreements.

content:
When contracting using the framework agreement method, the announcement thereof shall clarify the following:
1- Specifying whether the framework agreement is closed, or open, so that –after concluding the agreement and in accordance with its terms– new contractors, undertakers, or suppliers may join as parties thereto.
2- The procedures to be followed for submitting an application to join the framework agreement, and the required qualification criteria.
3- The most important provisions and conditions required in the agreement.
4- Description of the subject matter of the agreement.
5- Any other information or requirements contained in the tender documents for concluding framework agreements.
summary: This article specifies the information to be clarified in the announcement of a framework agreement, including whether it is closed or open.

content:
The framework agreement must include the following:
1- The number of parties to the agreement from among service providers.
2- The duration of the agreement, and whether it is open or closed.
3- The quantity of works and purchases expected to be requested.
4- Individual prices during the duration of the agreement, and the mechanism for reducing these prices, as if the contractor had offered or offered to others the works, purchases, or services at a lower price, or based on submitting reduced prices according to the quantities required.
5- Conditions of the agreement that will be signed after the award.
6- Conditions of the procedures for competition among the suppliers or contractors who are parties to the agreement.
7- Governmental entities that may issue purchase orders based on the agreement.
8- Mechanisms for delivering and receiving goods, or performing services.
9- Method of disbursing the financial consideration.
10- Mechanism for updating procedures in the specifications of the agreement during its implementation period, provided that this does not affect the essence of the agreement.
11- Rules governing the relationship between all parties to the agreement, and the procedures to be followed in the event of any dispute among them.
12- General and special conditions and specifications of the works.
summary: This article specifies the necessary contents of a framework agreement, including the number of parties, duration, quantities, prices, and competition conditions.

content:
The announcement of the framework agreement is subject to the provisions of the announcement of the contract method used to conclude the framework agreement. And the governmental entity, when concluding an open framework agreement, shall publish the invitation to join on the portal and its website throughout the duration of the agreement, provided that this invitation shall include the following:
1- Name and address of the governmental entity.
2- Qualifications required to be available in the competitors wishing to join.
3- The time period permitted for submitting a request to join.
summary: This article stipulates that the announcement of a framework agreement is subject to the provisions of the contract method used, and that an invitation to join shall be published if it is open.

content:
1- Authorization must be granted between the governmental entity and the undertaker, supplier, or service provider, in accordance with the conditions stipulated in the framework agreement.
2- If there is more than one supplier, undertaker, or service provider as parties to the agreement, a closed competition may be held among them in accordance with the conditions of the agreement.
3- The duration of the closed framework agreement must not exceed (three) years, and in the open framework agreement (four) years. The expiry of the framework agreement shall not affect any contract or authorization that arose during its validity period.
summary: This article specifies the procedures for authorization in a framework agreement, the possibility of holding a closed competition, and the duration of the agreement.

content:
Taking into account the provisions of Article (thirty-four) of the system, the governmental entity may use the reverse auction method to purchase goods available from more than one supplier, undertaker, or service provider, in accordance with the following conditions:
1- That the auction is limited to ready-made goods available in the market.
2- That the cost of the tender does not exceed (five million) riyals.
3- That the auction is carried out through the portal, ensuring the integrity of the procedures and transparency and achieving freedom of competition.
4- That the electronic reverse auction procedures shall include equality, justice, and equal opportunities among competitors.
5- The competitor shall be informed of the ranking of his price and the prices of other competitors without disclosing their identities.
6- That the time for the beginning and end of the reverse auction is specified, and the possibility of extending the rounds if more than one bid is equal, and also if the entity deems the prices inappropriate.
7- That the number of competitors in the electronic reverse auction shall not be less than (three) competitors, and the tender shall be cancelled if a number of competitors withdraw and only two or fewer remain.
8- Those wishing to enter the reverse auction shall submit a preliminary guarantee in accordance with the conditions of the auction, upon submitting their preliminary bids.
9- The entity shall examine the bids of the bidders and ensure that they conform to the technical terms and specifications before they enter the auction.
summary: This article specifies the conditions for an electronic reverse auction, including limiting it to ready-made goods, cost limits, the number of competitors, and submitting a preliminary guarantee.

content:
1- The electronic reverse auction shall be announced on the portal and the governmental entity’s website.
2- The announcement must include the technical terms and specifications and the final deadline for registering those wishing to participate in the electronic reverse auction; provided that the period from the date of the announcement until the deadline for registering participation requests shall not be less than fifteen days.
summary: This article specifies the procedures for announcing a reverse auction, including publication on the portal and website, and specifying the registration deadline.

content:
1- The award criteria in the electronic reverse auction are based on price, and the winning bid shall be the lowest price bid.
2- All competitors shall have equal and continuous opportunities to submit their prices or bids.
3- In the event of a malfunction in the electronic system through which the auction is conducted, the auction procedures shall be stopped immediately, provided that they shall resume during official working hours on the date specified for the auction, and the auction shall be cancelled if this is not possible.
summary: This article specifies the award criteria in a reverse auction, including the lowest price winning, and procedures for handling technical malfunctions.

content:
The head of the governmental entity or his delegate shall form a committee that shall undertake the following:
1- Supervising the reverse auction procedure.
2- Preparing minutes that include the procedures carried out and its recommendations for awarding to the successful bidder, and submitting it to the authorized person for approval of the award.
summary: This article mandates forming a committee to supervise the reverse auction, preparing minutes, and recommending the award.

content:
The contracting of the authority for industry localization and knowledge transfer shall be in accordance with the following controls:
1- That the localization of industry or the transfer of knowledge shall not result in a monopoly of that industry or knowledge.
2- That the changes and developments in technology, industry, and knowledge shall be taken into account when concluding agreements.
3- That the authority shall do the following:
A- Coordinate with the Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency and the relevant entities –each according to its competence– to prepare a feasibility study for the industry targeted for localization or the knowledge to be transferred, provided that the study shall include the optimal contracting method, the expected opportunities, and the impact of localizing that industry or transferring knowledge on enhancing economic development.
B- Submit the feasibility study to the ministry for consideration and approval; in preparation for completing what is required in this regard.
C- Coordinate with the Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency and the relevant entities –after the ministry’s approval– to prepare the terms and specifications documents and contract templates; in preparation for contracting.
D- Including in the agreement to be concluded with the contractor a specification of the percentages of government entities’ purchases from the products of that industry or knowledge, provided that the determination of percentages shall be coordinated with the beneficiary entities.
summary: This article specifies the controls for contracting on industry localization and knowledge transfer, including avoiding monopolies, preparing a feasibility study, and specifying government purchase percentages.

content:
Contracting using the competition method shall be for the purpose of preparing designs, plans, models, or other artistic and intellectual works in accordance with the following controls:
1- The competition shall be announced on the portal and the governmental entity’s website, provided that the announcement shall include –at a minimum– the following information:
A- General specifications of the works.
B- Number of winners and the rewards granted to them, provided that they shall not exceed three.
C- Criteria for comparing the bids submitted.
D- Date and place for submitting bids and communication and inquiry mechanisms
2- The bid examination committee shall examine the bids submitted and choose the winning bids and rank them according to the criteria set, and it may, for this purpose, interview any of the bidders to discuss their bid.
3- The competition method is exempted from submitting guarantees and related provisions.
4- The intellectual property of the contents of the winning bids shall be vested in the governmental entity.
summary: This article specifies the controls for contracting using a competition method, including announcing the competition, the number of winners, comparison criteria, and that intellectual property of winning bids is vested in the governmental entity.

content: Taking into account the provisions of Article (thirty-seven) of the system, the bid shall be submitted in two electronic files for works and purchases whose estimated value is (five million) riyals or more, and the governmental entity may require this for works and purchases whose value is less than (five million) riyals, as it deems in the best interest.
summary: This article mandates submitting bids in two electronic files for works exceeding 5 million riyals, with the possibility of requiring this for lower value works.

content:
1- The bid shall be submitted electronically after the competitor enters the required data in the tender documents through the portal in an encrypted file, or two encrypted files if it is required to submit two technical and financial bids.
2- As an exception to paragraph (1) of this article; for works and purchases executed outside the Kingdom by foreign persons, the governmental entity may stipulate in the tender documents that competitors may submit their bids in writing on their own papers, and the decisive factor in case of a discrepancy shall be what the governmental entity has stipulated as terms and conditions in its approved templates.
3- The bid –and all its attachments– shall be submitted pursuant to a formal letter signed by the submitter or by those who have the legal right of representation.
4- No bid that arrives after the deadline for submitting bids shall be considered.
5- A copy of the documents referred to in Article (thirteen) of these bylaws shall be submitted with the bid.
summary: This article specifies the method for submitting bids, electronically or in writing in exceptional cases, requiring a formal letter, and not considering late bids.

content:
1- The bidder applying to execute works and purchases must investigate –before submitting his bid– the nature, data, and details of the works applied for, the circumstances accompanying their execution, and what may affect the categories of his bid and the risks of his obligations.
2- The governmental entity shall provide an opportunity for competitors to conduct field visits to the project site if this is possible according to its nature.
summary: This article mandates that bidders investigate work details before submitting bids, and providing an opportunity for field visits.

content: The competitor is not permitted to submit an alternative bid with the original bid unless the tender documents stipulate this, in accordance with specific terms and specifications set by the governmental entity.
summary: This article prohibits submitting alternative bids unless stipulated in the tender documents.

content: The bid that violates the terms, specifications, and tender documents shall be excluded, and the bid examination committee may see otherwise if the violation is a formality and does not affect the bidder’s ability to comply with the terms and specifications.
summary: This article mandates the exclusion of bids violating terms, with the possibility of not excluding if the violation is formal.

content:
1- If it is not possible to submit bids through the portal in accordance with paragraph (2) of Article (eight) of these bylaws, they may be submitted in sealed envelopes via registered mail, or delivered to the governmental entity at the place specified for receiving bids with a receipt showing the date and time of delivery.
2- The entity shall upload the bids submitted in paper form to the portal to keep them in its records, after they are opened by the bid opening committee.
summary: This article specifies the method for submitting bids if the portal is unavailable, and the need to upload paper bids to the portal after opening.

content: The names of the competitors who submitted their bids shall be announced on the portal, after the deadline for submitting bids and opening them. If it is not possible to announce them on the portal, they shall be announced on the governmental entity’s website.
summary: This article mandates announcing competitor names on the portal or the entity's website.

content:
1- If the governmental entity is unable to decide on the award during the validity period of the bids, the bid examination committee shall prepare minutes explaining the reasons and justifications for the delay in deciding on the award, and the entity shall notify the bidders of its desire to extend the validity of their bids for a period not exceeding another (ninety) days.
2- Those bidders who agree to the extension must extend their guarantees and notify the governmental entity thereof within (two weeks) from the date of notification of the request for extension. Those who do not apply within this period shall be considered as not agreeing to extend their bids, and their preliminary guarantee shall be returned to them in this case.
3- If the periods mentioned in this article have passed, the governmental entity is not permitted to extend the validity of the bids unless with the approval of the ministry based on justifiable reasons, otherwise the tender shall be cancelled.
summary: This article specifies procedures for extending bid validity if the award is not decided within the specified period, requiring ministry approval for further extensions.

content: The bidder may withdraw his bid before the deadline for receiving bids, and the governmental entity shall return his preliminary guarantee.
summary: This article permits bid withdrawal before the deadline, with the return of the preliminary guarantee.

content:
1- The competitor must submit his price in accordance with the approved terms, specifications, and bill of quantities, and he is not permitted to make any amendments or express any reservations thereto or delete any item from the items or specifications of the tender, and the bid that violates this shall be excluded.
2- Individual and total bid prices shall be recorded in the bill of quantities numerically and in writing in the local currency, unless it is stipulated to submit them in another currency.
3- The bidder is not permitted to make any amendments, erasures, or obliterations in the price list, and any corrections made by the bidder must be rewritten numerically and in writing and signed.
4- The bid may be excluded if the price items that have been amended, erased, or obliterated exceed (10%) of the price list or the total value of the bid.
5- The bidder is not permitted to leave any item of the tender without pricing, unless the tender conditions permit this.
summary: This article specifies the method for writing bid prices, prohibiting amendments or deletions, and the possibility of excluding the bid if there are significant amendments.

content:
1- A bid submitted without a preliminary guarantee shall not be accepted, and the governmental entity must accept an incomplete guarantee if the percentage of the deficiency does not exceed (10%) of the value of the required guarantee. In this case, before recommending the award to the submitter of the incomplete guarantee, the bid examination committee shall request that he complete the deficiency in the guarantee within a period determined by the committee not exceeding (ten) working days, otherwise he shall be considered as having withdrawn and his preliminary guarantee shall not be returned to him.
2- The original letter of preliminary guarantee shall be submitted with the bid, provided that it shall be valid for a period of not less than (ninety) days from the date specified for opening the bids. If the guarantee is short in duration by not more than (thirty) days, the bid examination committee –before recommending the award to the submitter of the incomplete guarantee– shall request that he complete the deficiency in the guarantee within a period determined by it, otherwise he shall be considered as having withdrawn and his preliminary guarantee shall not be returned to him, and one or two days shall not be considered a deficiency in the duration of the guarantee.
3- The governmental entity shall request an extension of the preliminary guarantee for the party awarded the works if the expiry date of its validity is before the submission of the final guarantee.
4- Preliminary guarantees shall be returned to the bidders who were not awarded the works after deciding on the award, as well as in the event of cancelling the tender, or after the expiry of the time specified for the validity of the bids, unless the bidder expresses his desire to continue to be bound by his bid in accordance with the provisions of the system and these bylaws.
5- Other than what is mentioned above and in matters for which there is no provision that requires confiscating the preliminary guarantee, the preliminary guarantees shall be returned to their owners, and the governmental entity may, at its discretion or at the request of the bidders, release their preliminary guarantees before deciding on the award, if it appears after opening the bids and disclosing the prices that the prices of those bids are high or violate the terms and specifications in a manner that prevents the award to any of them.
summary: This article specifies the conditions for a preliminary guarantee, detailing procedures for handling incomplete guarantees, and the possibility of returning or extending them.

content:
The head of the governmental entity or his delegate shall issue a decision to form one or more committees to open bids, in accordance with the following controls:
1- The number of committee members shall not be less than three in addition to its chairman.
2- The formation decision shall stipulate the appointment of a vice-chairman who shall replace the chairman in his absence.
3- The committee shall be reconstituted every three years.
summary: This article mandates forming a bid opening committee, specifying the number of members, appointing a vice-chairman, and reconstituting the committee every three years.

content:
Taking into account the provisions of Article (forty-four) of the system, the bid opening committee shall adhere to the following:
1- Opening bids immediately after the deadline for receiving them, and in bids that include two electronic files, the committee shall open only the technical file in the presence of those bidders who wish to be present.
2- If the bid is submitted in two electronic files, the technical bids, after opening them, the financial bids, before opening them, and the committee’s minutes shall be referred to the bid examination committee.
3- If the bid opening committee is unable to carry out its work for justifiable reasons, the date for opening bids shall be postponed for the necessary period –after the approval of the head of the governmental entity or his delegate– and another date shall be set and the applicants for the tender shall be notified thereof, and in this case, it is not permissible to accept new bids during the postponement period.
4- The bid opening committee shall verify the confidentiality and integrity of the bids and their conformity with the provisions of the system and these bylaws, and it shall record in its minutes the number of bids submitted, and give each bid a serial number in the form of a common fraction; the numerator being the bid number and the denominator being the number of bids submitted.
5- The bid opening committee shall announce the name of the bidder, his total price and any increase or reduction thereon in the original bid letter, whether he has submitted a preliminary guarantee and its value, and whether he has submitted the required documents. In bids that are in two electronic files, the committee shall only announce the name of the bidder.
