6- The chairman of the bid opening committee and all its members shall list the samples and specifications of the devices and materials (catalogues) submitted with the bid, and sign the original bid letter, the bill of quantities, the bank guarantee letter, and the certificates attached with the bid and the minutes in which the committee records its procedures.
7- The bid opening committee is not permitted to exclude any bid or request that bidders correct errors or address the remarks contained in their bids, and it shall refrain from receiving any bids, envelopes, letters, or samples submitted to it by bidders during the bid opening session.
8- The bid opening committee shall record the contents of the bids it has opened. If the tender does not require submitting the bid in two electronic files, the committee shall record any amendments, corrections, or obliterations in the prices contained in the bid, and it must also list the unpriced items or those whose individual or total prices have not been recorded; numerically and in writing.
9- The bid opening committee –if the tender requires submitting bids in two electronic files– shall not open the financial bids except after the bid examination committee returns those bids to it, and the bid opening committee shall apply the procedures stipulated in this chapter when opening the financial bids.
10- After the bid opening committee has completed its work, it shall refer its minutes and the tender documents to the bid examination committee, within the period specified for it pursuant to paragraph (3) of Article (forty-four) of the system.
summary: This article specifies the procedures of the bid opening committee, detailing procedures for opening electronic bids, ensuring confidentiality and integrity, and preparing minutes.

content:
1- Extending the receipt of bids and postponing their opening shall be in the following cases:
A- If it appears that the statutory period for receiving bids referred to in Article (thirty-four) of these bylaws has not been completed, the governmental entity shall announce the extension of bid acceptance and postpone their opening to complete this period in accordance with the procedures for announcing public tenders, notifying purchasers of tender documents thereof.
B- If there are acceptable reasons for extending the receipt of bids; such as discovering material errors in the bill of quantities or if the governmental entity amends the tender documents and conditions or based on a justified request from most purchasers of tender documents or if no bids are submitted for the tender or if it is not possible to open the bids electronically.
2- The extension of bid acceptance and the postponement of opening shall be announced for an appropriate period in accordance with the procedures for announcing public tenders, notifying purchasers of tender documents thereof.
summary: This article specifies the cases in which extending bid receipt and postponing opening are permitted, mandating announcement thereof.

content:
1- Taking into account the provisions of Article (forty-five) of the system, the number of members of the bid examination committee –in addition to its chairman– shall not be less than three, including the financial controller, a member with statutory qualifications, and a member with technical knowledge of the nature of the works and purchases subject to the tender. The committee formation decision shall stipulate the appointment of a vice-chairman from among its members who shall replace him in his absence and a reserve member for each member of the committee, and the committee and its secretary shall be reconstituted every (three) years. 
2- As an exception to what is mentioned in paragraph (1) of this article; for works and purchases executed abroad, it is not required that the financial controller be among the formation of bid examination committees, provided that this does not violate the minimum number of committee members referred to in paragraph (1) of this article.
summary: This article specifies the formation of a bid examination committee, specifying members, reconstitution every three years, with an exception for the financial controller in foreign works.

content: The bid examination committee shall adhere to the evaluation criteria and tender conditions when evaluating bids.
summary: This article mandates the bid examination committee's adherence to evaluation criteria and tender conditions.

content:
1- Taking into account any specific provision, the bid examination committee may request –in writing– that bidders clarify any data or ambiguity in their bids; provided that this does not violate equal opportunities and equality among competitors and does not lead to changes in essential matters such as prices, and that it shall not lead to converting a bid that violates the terms and specifications into an acceptable bid, and the competitors shall respond to the clarification requests issued regarding their bids in writing.
2- The competent departments at the governmental entity are not permitted to contact bidders as indicated in paragraph (1) of this article, except with prior approval from the bid examination committee, and in each case separately.
summary: This article permits the bid examination committee to request clarifications from bidders, considering equal opportunities and not changing essential matters.

content: If the bidder does not have any of the required certificates referred to in Article (thirteen) of these bylaws, or if those certificates have expired, the bidder shall be given a period determined by the bid examination committee not exceeding (ten) working days to complete those certificates, and if he does not submit them within the specified time; he shall be excluded from the tender and his preliminary guarantee shall be confiscated.
summary: This article grants a period to complete required certificates, excluding the bidder and confiscating the guarantee if they are not submitted.

content:
1- If the tender requires submitting two technical and financial bids, the bid examination committee shall do the following:
A- Return the financial bids related to the technically accepted bids to the bid opening committee to open them in accordance with the procedures stipulated in Chapter (four) of Section (three) of these bylaws.
B- Open the estimated price file after the committee receives the minutes of the bid opening committee for the technically accepted financial bids.
2- If the tender requires submitting the bid in one file, the bid examination committee shall open the estimated price file after receiving the minutes of the bid opening committee.
summary: This article specifies the procedures of the bid examination committee for opening financial bids, depending on whether the bids are in one or two files.

content:
1- If the competitor omits to put prices for some items, the bid examination committee may exclude his bid or consider the unpriced items as loaded on the total value of the bid, and the competitor shall be considered as agreeing to this condition when submitting his bid.
2- In supply contracts, the competitor shall be considered as if he did not submit a bid for the unpriced items, and his bid shall be excluded if the tender conditions do not permit division.
3- If the contractor does not execute the items loaded on the total value of the bid, they shall be executed at his expense or the equivalent cost shall be deducted; according to the average price of the item among the bidders or the price estimated by the bid examination committee in the event of a single bid or if the unpriced items are not priced by the competitors.
4- If the governmental entity amends its decision regarding the execution of any item from among the items loaded on the total value of the bid, the equivalent cost thereof shall be deducted in accordance with the method specified for pricing it, referred to in paragraph (3) of this article.
5- Taking into account the provisions of Article (sixty-four) of these bylaws; the bid examination committee may not exclude the bid that contains minor differences that do not materially alter the terms and specifications specified in the tender documents, or if the bid contains errors that can be corrected without affecting the essence of the bid in accordance with Articles (eighty-one) and (eighty-two) of these bylaws.
6- The bid examination committee may subject the bid that contains minor differences or reservations –while meeting the terms and specifications– to detailed evaluation and comparison with the bids, taking into account the effects of these differences or reservations –if any– on the costs.
7- Taking into account the provisions of paragraphs (5) and (6) of this article; the bid examination committee shall exclude the bid that contains material differences in the terms and specifications of the tender documents.
summary: This article specifies the procedures of the bid examination committee in the event of unpriced items, or minor or material differences in bids.

content: If two or more bids are equal in the overall evaluation, the award shall be made to the lowest price bid, and if they are equal in this, the governmental entity shall divide the tender among the equal bids; if the terms and specifications of the tender permit this, and if division is not stipulated, priority in the award shall be given to small and medium-sized local establishments, and a closed competition shall be held among the equal bids if this is not possible.
summary: This article specifies the award procedures if two or more bids are equal, including awarding to the lowest price, dividing the tender, or prioritizing small and medium-sized enterprises.

content:
1- The bid examination committee shall review the bill of quantities and prices contained in the bid –whether in their individual items or their total– and make the necessary arithmetic corrections in the bid.
2- If there is a discrepancy between the price shown in writing and the price shown in numerals, the price shown in writing shall be taken, and if there is a discrepancy between the unit price and the price of its total, the unit price shall be taken, except in the event of material errors in the price shown in numerals or the price of the total units –such as placing a decimal point in the wrong place–, then the bid examination committee may take those prices.
3- The bid examination committee may recommend excluding the bid if the arithmetic errors in the prices after correction in accordance with the provisions of this article exceed (10%) of the price list or the total value of the bid, either by increase or decrease.
summary: This article specifies the procedures of the bid examination committee in reviewing prices and making arithmetic corrections, with the possibility of excluding the bid if errors exceed 10%.

content:
1- The bid examination committee shall verify the reasonableness of the price of the best bid that conforms to the terms and specifications; by referring to the last prices previously dealt with, the prevailing prices in the market, and the indicative estimated prices for the tender.
2- The bid examination committee may re-price the items if it finds that they have been set in an unstudied manner and do not represent the actual price of the items, provided that this does not affect the total price of the bid. If the competitor refuses re-pricing, he shall be excluded from the tender and his guarantee shall be returned.
3- The bid that is based on a percentage reduction or a specific amount from the lowest bids shall be excluded.
summary: This article mandates the bid examination committee to verify price reasonableness, the possibility of re-pricing, and excluding bids based on percentage reductions from the lowest bids.

content:
Taking into account the provisions of Article (forty-seven) of the system, the following must be adhered to when negotiating:
1- Awarding to the bidder whose price reaches the specified or required amount.
2- That the cancellation of the tender shall be by recommendation from the bid examination committee to the authorized person for cancellation; who shall be obligated to cancel it in that case.
summary: This article specifies negotiation procedures, including awarding to those whose price reaches the required amount, and cancelling the tender by recommendation from the bid examination committee.

content: When discussing with the bidder whose prices are less than (25%) or more of the estimated cost in accordance with the provisions of Article (forty-eight) of the system; the bid examination committee must take into account the bidder’s efficiency as if prior qualification had been carried out for him, or his technical bid was subject to evaluation if the tender requires two technical and financial bids. The bid examination committee must also take into account the nature of the required works, and that low prices do not affect their execution; as in supply contracts and the like.
summary: This article mandates considering the bidder's efficiency when discussing bids whose prices are less than 25% of the estimated cost, and considering the nature of the works.

content:
1- The governmental entity shall announce the winning bid in the tender on the portal and notify the bidder thereof, and the announcement shall include at least the following information:
A- Winning bidder.
B- Information about the project.
C- Total value of the project.
D- Contract execution period and place.
2- Other competitors shall be notified of the tender results, and the reasons for their exclusion, including the technical scores of their bids.
3- The portal shall publish the results and data of tenders and purchases whose value exceeds (one hundred thousand) riyals, within (thirty) days of contracting at the most, provided that the information on each contract shall be published separately, and that this information shall include the following:
A- Name and address of the contractor and type of contract.
B- Duration, value, and place of execution of the contract.
C- Site handover date, and works receipt date.
4- Purchases of weapons, ammunition, military equipment, and their supplies and those related to national security are exempted from the announcement and publication.
summary: This article specifies the information for announcing the winning bid, and publishing tender results on the portal, with exceptions for national security.

content:
1- The costs of tender documents –if any– shall be returned to the bidders if the tender is cancelled in the following cases:
A- The existence of material errors in the tender documents.
B- Violation of the tender procedures of the provisions of the system and these bylaws.
C- If the public interest requires cancelling the tender.
D- Committing any of the violations mentioned in paragraph (3) of Article (fifty-one) of the system, for those competitors who have no relation to those violations.
E- The prices of the bids exceeding the approved amounts.
2- The costs of tender documents shall be returned to the purchaser if the receipt of bids is extended for the second time, and the purchaser expresses his unwillingness to continue in the tender.
3- The costs of tender documents shall not be returned if the cancellation is after opening the bids, except for those who submitted their bids to the tender.
summary: This article specifies the cases for refunding tender document costs, in the event of cancellation.

content:
The governmental entity must adhere to the suspension period in accordance with the following controls:
1- The suspension period must not be less than (five) working days or more than (ten) working days from the date of issuing the award decision and announcing it, and the entity shall be committed to announcing it on the electronic portal.
2- If it is not possible to announce it on the portal or the governmental entity’s website for technical reasons, the competitors shall be notified thereof via email.
3- Taking into account the provisions of Article (seventy-seven) of the system, the governmental entity shall receive objections to the award decision or any of its procedures through the portal.
4- The governmental entity is not permitted to accept any objection after the suspension period ends.
5- The award decision shall not be considered valid until the suspension period ends, and the objections shall be decided upon, if any.
summary: This article specifies the suspension period after the award decision, and the procedures for receiving objections.

content:
1- The entity shall specify a date for signing the contract after submitting the final guarantee, and if the contractor is late for the specified date without an acceptable excuse, he shall be notified thereof, and if he does not attend to sign the contract within (fifteen) days from the date of his notification, the contract shall be terminated by decision of the authorized person, and the final guarantee shall be confiscated, without prejudice to the governmental entity’s right to recourse against its contractor for compensation for any damage incurred, and the committee stipulated in Article (eighty-eight) of the system shall be provided with a copy of the decision; to consider this violation.
2- Taking into account paragraph (2) of Article (fifty-five) of the system, it is not permitted to begin executing the contracted works before signing the contract.
summary: This article specifies the contract signing date, termination procedures in case of delay, and final guarantee confiscation.

content:
1- The contract shall be prepared in at least six copies; one copy shall be given to the contractor, one copy to the department responsible for supervising execution, one copy to the department responsible for accounting, one copy to the General Auditing Bureau, one copy to the Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency or the General Authority for Military Industries as the case may be, and one copy to the authority.
2- The General Authority for Zakat and Tax shall be notified of the information it requests about the contract, which includes the following:
A- Name and address of the contractor.
B- Subject matter of the contract, its total value, and its financial terms.
C- Date of commencement and expiry of its execution.
D- Any amendments made to the contract.
keywords: General Authority for Zakat and Tax
summary: This article specifies the number of contract copies, recipients of those copies, and notification to the General Authority for Zakat and Tax.

content:
1- Correspondence and notifications between the governmental entity and its contractor shall be through the electronic portal, and the governmental entity may, in addition to this, use one of the following methods:
A- National address.
B- Postal address through companies providing postal services.
C- Approved email, and text messages.
2- The notification carried out in accordance with the provision of paragraph (1) of this article shall produce its legal effects from the date of its issuance.
summary: This article specifies the methods for correspondence and notifications between the governmental entity and the contractor, considering notifications valid from the date of issuance.

content: The governmental entity may stipulate in the contract the exclusion of the summer vacation period in cleaning, maintenance, and other service contracts with educational entities and the like, and reducing the number of workers and unnecessary contract elements; if those entities carry out limited activity during that period.
summary: This article permits excluding the summer vacation period and reducing workers in specific contracts.

content:
1- In continuous execution service contracts that depend on performance, the governmental entity may set the conditions referred to in paragraph (3) of Article (fifty-six) of the system, in accordance with the following controls:
A- That the conditions reflect a focus on the contract outputs and the extent to which they meet the actual needs of the entity instead of merely fulfilling the contractor’s obligations.
B- That appropriate performance measures be set for works with technical specifications that depend on performance and outputs.
C- That payments be linked to performance measures so that it is possible to verify that the executed works meet the actual needs of the entity; in terms of the required quality level.
2- The governmental entity may terminate the contract if the contractor’s performance level declines, provided that he obtains a score of less than (70%) in the performance level for three consecutive times, and does not rectify his situation in accordance with what is mentioned in paragraph (2) of Article (seventy-six) of the system.
summary: This article specifies the conditions for continuous execution service contracts, and the possibility of contract termination if performance levels decline.

content:
1- All governmental entities shall be committed to submitting their contracts whose execution period exceeds (one) year or whose value is (five million) riyals or more to the ministry for financial review before signing them.
2- Governmental entities shall be committed to reviewing their contracts from the legal and drafting points of view and ensuring their conformity with the approved contract templates, provided that non-standard contracts shall be drafted according to their nature in accordance with the system and these bylaws and by referring to the approved contract templates, and reviewing them in accordance with this paragraph before submitting them to the ministry for financial review.
summary: This article mandates governmental entities to submit contracts to the ministry for financial and legal review before signing.

content:
Firstly: The governmental entity shall contract to execute its works and projects in accordance with the following types of contracts:
1- General construction contract.
2- Continuous execution service contracts.
3- Supply contract.
4- Information technology contract
5- Consultancy services contract.
6- Project management contract.
7- Design contract.
8- Manufacturing contract.
9- Movable property lease contract.
10- Movable property sale contract.
11- Any other contracts for executing specific works for the governmental entity.
Secondly: When executing works and purchases outside the Kingdom, the governmental entity shall be committed to applying the approved contract templates for these works, and for countries that require applying their contract templates, it is permissible to apply those templates provided that they do not violate the provisions of the system and these bylaws.
summary: This article lists the types of contracts the governmental entity may use, specifying procedures for foreign contracts.

content:
The governmental entity may contract for executing works in accordance with any of the following methods:
1- Contracts where accounting is based on the actual measurement in kind of the quantities, items, and numbers that have been executed, in accordance with the following controls:
A- That they be in general construction and service works, in accordance with the calculated bill of quantities, and based on the designs and plans previously approved.
B- That the prices for the work items are fixed but the quantities are not precisely specified or are difficult to estimate definitively.
C- That the financial statements be disbursed in installments according to the works actually completed, provided that those works are measured at the works execution site.
2- Turnkey contract, in accordance with the following controls:
A- That it be in major construction and infrastructure contracts and industrial facilities, and the like.
B- That the contractor is responsible for the conformity of the designs and execution on site.
C- That the contract is executed in accordance with the technical specifications contained in the tender conditions.
D- That the contract is executed for a lump sum in accordance with the specifications determined by the governmental entity.
E- The governmental entity may include equipment and furnishing items in turnkey contracts.
3- Lump sum contract, in accordance with the following controls:
A- That it be in simple works or those whose quantities cannot be measured, or the remaining works after executing the project.
B- That the lump sum covers all the works.
4- Contracting according to a margin or a specific profit amount, and this method shall be used in officially priced materials, or what can be priced by the governmental entity; provided that the entity sets an upper limit for costs that the contractor should not exceed without its approval, and that the contractor submits detailed periodic reports on those costs to the governmental entity.
5- Contracting according to performance according to specific quantitative criteria.
6- Contracting with consultants to supervise projects, at a specific percentage of the value of the construction contract if the consultant does not participate in setting the terms and specifications, or for a lump sum otherwise. Provided that the percentage or lump sum does not exceed (3%) of the contract value and this percentage may not be increased under any circumstances, and a lump sum may be added that may not be exceeded in the event of extending the contract or making changes to the project.
7- Any other contract method by agreement with the ministry.
And the contract templates clarify the conditions for using the contract methods mentioned.
summary: This article lists the different contract methods, including actual measurement, turnkey, lump sum, and others.

content:
1- In general construction tenders, the governmental entity shall, before floating the tender, verify the safety and readiness of the work site and its suitability for commencing the works subject to the tender.
2- As an exception to what is mentioned in paragraph (1) of this article; if there is an urgent need to save time in executing tender procedures, the governmental entity may float the tender before verifying the safety and readiness of the work site, provided that the governmental entity mentions in the tender documents that the award and signing of the contract shall not be carried out except after verifying the safety and readiness of the work site.
3- The governmental entity shall deliver the work site in general construction contracts within the period specified in paragraph (2) of Article (fifty-nine) of the system, and if the governmental entity is late in delivering the site within that period, the contractor may request terminating the contract in accordance with the provisions of Article (one hundred and thirty-three) of these bylaws.
4- The work site shall be delivered on a preliminary basis before the expiry of the existing contract in continuous execution service contracts where commencing work requires preparation to ensure the continuity of service and its non-interruption, then the site shall be delivered to commence executing the contract after the previous contract ends, and the tender conditions shall stipulate the preparation period, which shall not be counted within the contract period.
summary: This article specifies site handover procedures in general construction contracts, with an exception in urgent cases, and site handover in service contracts.

content:
1- If the contractor is late, slow, or refuses to receive the work site, he shall be notified thereof. If he does not receive the site within (fifteen) days from the date of his notification, the entity shall prepare minutes handing over the site to the contractor judicially, and the contractor shall be notified thereof with a notification to commence execution within (fifteen) days from the date of the notification. If this period expires and work has not commenced, the contract may be terminated in accordance with the provisions of Article (seventy-six) of the system.
2- If the contractor claims that there are obstacles preventing him from receiving the work site, he does not have the right to refuse receipt; provided that he is allowed to record any reservations he may have regarding the site in the site handover minutes, and the governmental entity shall verify the safety and readiness of the site to commence execution.
summary: This article specifies procedures for handling contractor delays in receiving the work site, with the possibility of judicial handover, and recording reservations.

content:
1- The contractor in general construction contracts shall be responsible for reviewing the engineering and technical designs in full detail, and he shall notify the governmental entity immediately upon discovering any errors in the specifications or plans or any other errors that may affect the safety of the facilities. The contractor shall also be committed to reviewing the reports and recommendations of soil testing, without exempting the designing or supervising consultant from their contractual responsibilities.
2- The contractor is not permitted to relinquish his obligations based on the governmental entity’s failure to fulfill its obligations.
3- The contractors and the governmental entity must execute their contracts in accordance with their terms and in good faith and as required by the smooth running of the public facility and its interest.
summary: This article specifies the contractor's responsibility in general construction contracts, including reviewing designs, notifying the governmental entity of errors, and adhering to his obligations.

content:
1- Unless a shorter period is agreed upon, the contractor shall guarantee against any complete or partial collapse of what he has constructed for (ten) years from the date of its preliminary handover to the governmental entity, provided that the collapse results from a defect in execution.
2- In addition to the manufacturer’s guarantee, the supplier shall guarantee the goods, devices, equipment, and machinery against any defects or damage, in accordance with what is specified in the tender documents or the contract.
summary: This article specifies the contractor's guarantee period in construction contracts, and the supplier's guarantee for goods and devices.

content: Taking into account the provisions of paragraph (1) of Article (sixty-one) of the system, the governmental entity may increase the percentage of the final guarantee to exceed (5%) of the contract value if it deems that it is in the best interest of the project, provided that the prior approval of the minister is obtained before floating the works, and that percentage of the final guarantee is stipulated in the tender documents.
summary: This article permits increasing the final guarantee percentage above 5% with the minister's approval.

content: The entity shall request an extension of the validity of the final guarantee before its expiry in construction contracts if the contractor is late in executing maintenance and guarantee works, and this extends beyond the expiry of the guarantee year referred to in paragraph (1) of Article (one hundred and twenty-eight) of these bylaws.
summary: This article mandates requesting an extension of the final guarantee in construction contracts if the contractor delays maintenance work.

content: The guarantee for the advance payment must equal its value, and it must be valid until the full advance payment is recovered. The governmental entity shall notify the bank issuing the guarantee of reducing its value by the same percentage recovered from the advance payment in accordance with the statements and on the date of deduction; without a request from the contractor.
summary: This article specifies the conditions for an advance payment guarantee, equalling its value, and its validity until full recovery.

content:
1- The governmental entity shall request an extension of the validity of guarantees before their expiry if there are reasons specified for the extension pursuant to the system and these bylaws and the contract conditions.
2- The governmental entity shall direct the request for extension to the bank directly, and provide the contractor with a copy thereof. The extension shall be for the necessary period; provided that the request for extension shall indicate that the guarantee value must be paid to the entity immediately if the bank does not complete the extension procedures before the expiry of the guarantee validity period.
summary: This article specifies guarantee extension procedures, directing the request to the bank directly.

content:
1- If there are reasons for confiscating the bank guarantee, the governmental entity shall submit to the bid examination committee or the direct purchase bid examination committee, as the case may be; to study the case and submit a reasoned recommendation to the authorized person for the award, taking into account the effects of the confiscation and the guarantee validity period. The entity may request extending the guarantee for a reasonable period if the procedures for making a confiscation decision require this.
2- The guarantee may not be confiscated except for the reasons for which the guarantee was submitted, and the request for confiscation shall be limited to the guarantee specific to the operation in which the contractor breached his obligations, and it shall not extend to confiscating the guarantees for other operations, whether with one entity or several entities.
3- When confiscating the preliminary guarantee in divided tenders, the confiscation shall be limited to a portion of the guarantee value proportionate to the value of the works awarded to the contractor.
4- If the governmental entity decides to confiscate the guarantee, it shall request its confiscation from the bank issuing the guarantee directly and using the phrase “guarantee confiscation” explicitly, and the bank shall respond to the request for confiscation immediately.
summary: This article specifies the procedures for confiscating a bank guarantee, requiring submission to the bid examination committee, and limiting confiscation to the specific operation where the contractor breached obligations.

content:
1- The governmental entity may accept a bank guarantee issued by a foreign bank provided that it is approved by the Saudi Arabian Monetary Authority, in cases where the competitor is unable to submit a guarantee from or through a Saudi bank for works and purchases executed outside the Kingdom.
2- If the guarantee is submitted by a foreign bank through a local bank, the local bank must adhere to the terms and rules of bank guarantees specified pursuant to the system and these bylaws.
3- The governmental entity must verify the validity of all guarantees submitted –pursuant to the system and these bylaws– immediately upon receiving those guarantees, through the banks issuing the guarantees.
4- The guarantee may be submitted by several banks, whereby each bank is committed to performing a specific percentage of the guarantee value.
5- The guarantee shall be payable upon the first request from the governmental entity without the need for a judicial ruling or a decision from an arbitration body.
6- The guarantee must be unconditional and non-cancellable, and its value must be free of any deductions related to taxes, fees, or any other expenses.
7- The governmental entity must have special records for monitoring the guarantees submitted by its contractors and following up on the procedures for requesting an extension of their validity, confiscation, or release.
8- Bank guarantees may be replaced from one bank to another, provided that the guarantee is not released until the replacement guarantee is obtained.
9- The governmental entity may accept bank guarantees issued by branches of foreign banks licensed in the Kingdom.
10- When executing works and purchases outside the Kingdom, the governmental entity may accept cash guarantees or bank checks in countries where it is not easy for foreign persons to obtain bank guarantees.
summary: This article specifies guarantee provisions, including accepting guarantees from foreign banks, the possibility of providing cash guarantees, and the need for records to monitor guarantees.

content:
1- Unless otherwise stipulated by law, the provisions, templates, and conditions of guarantees –referred to in the system and in these bylaws– shall apply to all guarantees requested by the governmental entity, including the guarantees required in public auctions for selling movables.
2- The templates and forms of bank guarantees specified by the ministry in accordance with the provisions of the system and these bylaws must be adhered to.
summary: This article mandates applying guarantee provisions to all requested guarantees, adhering to ministry-specified guarantee templates.

content:
The governmental entity may request that a portion of the bank guarantee be submitted in cash, in catering contracts and water supply contracts or in cases that require urgent securing, in accordance with the following controls:
1- That the amount of the cash guarantee does not exceed the cost of the works for a period of (five) days.
2- The amount of the cash guarantee shall be delivered to the governmental entity.
3- These amounts shall not be entered into the fund account or financial records at the entity, and shall be ready upon the request of the committee supervising the execution of the works, and shall be disbursed by the committee after approval by the department manager in the entity benefiting from the contract.
4- The entity shall notify the contractor to compensate what is disbursed from the amount immediately, and the amount shall be deducted from his dues if he is late in doing so.
5- The cash guarantee may not be used or confiscated for purposes other than those for which it was allocated.
6- The cash guarantee or what remains thereof shall be returned to the contractor after the execution of the contract ends, pursuant to the instrument delivered to the contractor.
7- The amount of the cash guarantee may be deposited in an account with the Saudi Arabian Monetary Authority or in a bank, in accordance with the financial and accounting instructions at the ministry.
summary: This article permits requesting a portion of the bank guarantee in cash in specific cases, specifying controls, and returning the amount to the contractor after execution.

content:
The governmental entity may disburse an advance payment to the contractor not exceeding (10%) of the total contract value, in accordance with the following conditions:
1- The value of the advance payment shall be disbursed after the contractor submits the guarantee therefor, and it shall be recovered from his dues in installments equal to the percentage of the advance payment, from the value of each statement, starting from the first statement.
2- It is not permissible to disburse an advance payment when extending existing contracts, or commissioning additional works.
3- The governmental entity may divide the advance payment and disburse it to the contractors in installments.
summary: This article permits disbursing an advance payment to the contractor not exceeding 10%, with conditions for submitting a guarantee, and not permitting disbursement when extending contracts or for additional works.

content:
The contractors’ dues shall be disbursed in installments according to the works completed, and after deducting any penalties or other deductions incurred by the contractor, in accordance with the following procedures:
1- After completing a percentage of the works, the contractor shall list what has actually been executed from the works, match them with the bill of quantities, and prepare a monthly or phased statement in accordance with the payment conditions specified in the contract, and submit it to the consultant or directly to the governmental entity if there is no consultant.
2- After receiving the statement, the project consultant shall inspect the works executed in kind and verify their conformity with the specifications and bill of quantities agreed upon in the contract, and prepare a report thereon that shall be submitted with the statement within (ten) working days from the date of receiving the statement.
3- The governmental entity shall complete the procedures for approving the statement, and submit the payment order to the ministry within (fifteen) working days from the date of receiving the consultant’s report or the statement submitted by the contractor.
4- The ministry shall disburse the payment order within a period not exceeding (forty-five) days from the date of its receipt. If the payment order is returned to the governmental entity for the purpose of amendment or clarification, the period mentioned in this article shall commence from the date the governmental entity resends the payment order after completing what is required in this regard.
5- In the event of a dispute between the project consultant and the contractor, the consultant shall submit a claim to the contractor attaching his reservations to the governmental entity within (ten) working days from the date of receiving the claim. The governmental entity shall decide on the dispute between them within (fifteen) working days of receiving the claim, provided that the governmental entity shall disburse the dues that are not subject to dispute.
summary: This article specifies the procedures for disbursing contractor dues in installments, with the role of the consultant, the governmental entity, the ministry, and dispute resolution procedures.

content: The value of foreign contracts may be disbursed by opening letters of credit, in accordance with the letter of credit bylaw approved by the ministry.
summary: This article permits disbursing the value of foreign contracts by opening letters of credit.

content:
1- Taking into account the provisions of item number (2) of this article, the final statement, which must not be less than (10%) in general construction contracts and (5%) in other contracts, shall be disbursed after the preliminary handover of the works, or the supply of purchases and the contractor submitting the following certificates:
- Work completion certificate from the governmental entity in charge of the project.
- Certificates that must be submitted pursuant to the approved contract templates.
2- The governmental entity may divide the final statement in contracts whose works can be divided and disburse each due amount for the completed portion that has met the receipt and acceptance conditions.
summary: This article specifies the conditions for disbursing the final statement, the statement percentage, and the possibility of dividing it.

content: The contractor may assign the amounts due to him pursuant to the contract after the approval of the contracting entity and in accordance with the assignment form approved by the ministry, provided that this does not violate the rights of the contractor’s employees, and the rights of suppliers and subcontractors, and what the governmental entity or other governmental entities have of rights against the contractor.
summary: This article permits assigning due amounts with entity approval, considering the rights of other parties.

content:
Except for fixed profit margin contracts, contract prices shall be amended in the cases specified pursuant to Article (sixty-eight) of the system by increase or decrease in accordance with the following provisions:
Firstly: Compensation shall be made in the event of amending the customs tariff, fees, taxes, or officially priced materials or services by increase –after the bid submission date–, taking into account the following:
1- That the contractor proves that he paid the customs tariff, fees, taxes, or officially priced materials or services on the basis of the categories amended by increase as a result of supplying materials specified for the contract works.
2- That the amendment of the customs tariff, fees, taxes, or officially priced materials or services has not been issued after the deadline for executing the contract.
3- That the contractor’s bearing thereof shall not be as a result of his delay in execution, unless he proves that the delay was due to reasons beyond his control.
And in all cases, the difference in fees, taxes, or officially priced materials or services shall be deducted from the contractor after their reduction; unless the contractor proves that he paid them on the basis of the categories before the amendment.
Secondly: Compensation shall be made for an increase in the prices of raw materials such as cement, iron, asphalt, ready-mix concrete, wood, pipes, or cables, or any other raw materials specified by the ministry or by agreement with it; in accordance with the following conditions:
1- That the change in prices is after the contractor submits his bid.
2- That this is not due to a delay in execution for reasons attributable to the contractor.
3- The prices of the items shall not be considered for amendment except where the change in market prices for one item exceeds a decrease or increase of (10%), in accordance with the price indicators issued by the competent entity.
4- That the change in prices results in an increase in the contract cost by more than (3%) of its total value.
5- The difference in the prices of raw materials specified pursuant to item (Secondly) of this article shall be deducted from the contractor if they decrease in accordance with the percentages and conditions referred to in the compensation for the increase.
Thirdly: Procedures for considering compensation:
1- If the contractor deems that he is entitled to any financial compensation in the cases referred to in Article (sixty-eight) of the system, he shall submit his claim supported by the necessary documents and evidence to the consultant or directly to the governmental entity in projects that do not require a consultant, within a period not exceeding (sixty) days from the occurrence of the event.
2- The consultant shall study the contractor’s claim within a period not exceeding (twenty-one) days from the date of receiving the complete claim, and submit a report thereon to the governmental entity.
3- After receiving the consultant’s report or the contractor’s claim, the governmental entity shall study the contractor’s request for compensation from the technical, financial, and legal aspects, then submit the report or claim and the results of the study to the bid examination committee to issue the necessary recommendation within a period not exceeding (forty-five) days from the date of receiving the report or claim.
4- The governmental entity shall submit the minutes of the bid examination committee after their approval by the head of the entity, accompanied by the documents related to the claim, to the committee stipulated in Article (eighty-six) of the system, to consider the contractor’s entitlement to compensation and issue the necessary decision in this regard within a period not exceeding (forty-five) days from the date of receiving the complete claim.
5- What the governmental entity pays to the contractor in compensation pursuant to this article must not exceed (20%) of the total contract value, provided that those compensations are paid directly by the governmental entity. The contractor shall apply to the administrative court to claim compensations exceeding the percentage specified in this paragraph.
6- The governmental entity is not permitted to consider compensation for any claims submitted by the contractor other than what is stipulated in Article (sixty-eight) of the system.
summary: This article specifies the cases for amending contract prices, with compensation procedures, the role of the consultant, the bid examination committee, and the administrative court.

content:
Taking into account the provisions of Article (sixty-nine) of the system, the governmental entity shall, if it decides to increase or reduce the contractor’s obligations or make any amendments or changes to the works contracted to be executed; take into account the following controls:
1- That the additional works shall be subject to the contract and not outside its scope.
2- That the necessary amendments or changes to the works serve the interest of the facility, provided that this does not lead to violating the terms and specifications or changing the scope of the works or the nature of the contract or its financial balance.
3- Verifying the availability of the necessary amounts to cover the value of the additional works before authorizing the contractor to carry them out.
4- If the additional works do not have similar items or quantities in the contract, they shall be submitted to the bid examination committee or the direct purchase bid examination committee, as the case may be, to study the request to assign those works and the suitability of the prices submitted by the contractor. If the contractor does not agree to what the committee concludes, the contract shall be concluded for their execution by other competitors in accordance with the provisions of the system and these bylaws.
5- It is not permissible to commission additional works after the governmental entity receives the works subject to the contract.
6- The authorized person for the award shall be responsible for issuing all orders related to increasing or reducing the contractor’s obligations and the periods due for additional works.
summary: This article specifies the controls for increasing or reducing contractor obligations, with the role of the bid examination committee, and the authority of the authorized person for the award.

content: The contractor is not permitted to execute any works or services not included in the quantities and items of the contract, except with special authorization, and the contractor shall not be entitled to the value of the works he executes in violation thereof.
summary: This article prohibits executing works or services not included in the contract except with special authorization.

content: Continuous execution service contracts, such as maintenance, cleaning, operation, and catering services may be extended by not more than (10%) of the total contract value as additional works, provided that this percentage has not been used up in executing other additional items or quantities.
summary: This article permits extending continuous execution service contracts by up to 10% as additional works.

content:
Without prejudice to the provisions of Article (seventy) of the system, the governmental entity shall, if the contractor submits a request to assign the contract or a portion thereof to another contractor; take into account the following:
1- The existence of justifiable reasons for the contractor to assign the entire contract or a portion thereof, and that the contractor has not previously assigned any other project during the three years preceding the conclusion of the contract to be assigned.
2- Submitting to the bid examination committee to study the assignment request and issue the necessary recommendation and submit it to the head of the governmental entity, provided that the committee shall clarify in its minutes the justifications and reasons it relied upon in its recommendation.
3- If the authorized person approves, the assignment request shall be submitted, along with the committee’s minutes and related documents, to the ministry for approval.
4- The assignment shall be pursuant to an assignment agreement concluded between the parties to the assignment and certified by the chamber of commerce, and shall include specifying the obligations of the parties towards the project and the governmental entity. The assignment agreement shall not be valid unless approved by the governmental entity.
5- That the assignee contractor has the conditions for dealing with the governmental entity, and that he is classified in the field and grade of the works assigned to him, and that he pass all the technical evaluation and qualification requirements if the project is subject to qualification or the governmental entity deems it necessary to qualify him, and that the assignment shall not result in damaging the project assigned or violating its benefit.
6- Assignment cases shall be registered after their approval in the contractor’s record on the portal.
summary: This article specifies the procedures for assigning a contract, requiring justifiable reasons, the role of the bid examination committee, and conditions for the new contractor.

content:
1- Taking into account the provisions of Article (seventy-one) of the system, the following are required for subcontracting:
A- Obtaining prior approval from the governmental entity before contracting.
B- That the contracts concluded with subcontractors shall include the quantities and works assigned to them and their contract prices in accordance with the project’s requirements, terms, and specifications.
C- That the subcontractor shall not be among the persons referred to in Article (fourteen) of these bylaws, and that he shall be licensed in the works contracted to be executed, and classified in the field and at the required grade if the works are subject to classification, and that he has the sufficient qualifications and capabilities to execute those works.
D- That the percentage of works and purchases assigned to the subcontractor does not exceed (30%) of the contract value.
E- That the main contractor shall be responsible before the governmental entity for the works contracted to be executed by the subcontractor in accordance with the terms and specifications stipulated in the contract.
F- That the subcontractor is not permitted to subcontract with any other subcontractor to execute the works contracted with him to execute.
G- That the main contractor submit a declaration permitting the governmental entity to disburse the dues of subcontractors for the parts they have executed from the project from his dues with the entity, in the event of his delay or failure to do so.
2- Subcontracting may be carried out for works and purchases exceeding (30%) and less than (50%) of the contract value; provided that prior approval is obtained from the Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency and the governmental entity, and that those works and purchases are assigned to more than one subcontractor who are qualified for this purpose.
summary: This article specifies subcontracting conditions, including governmental entity approval, the percentage of assigned works, and the main contractor's responsibility.

content: When setting delay penalties for works executed using the framework agreement method, the total value of the purchase order shall be the total value of the contract.
summary: This article specifies the method for calculating delay penalties in framework agreements.

content: When estimating penalties in contracts, the governmental entity must stipulate the method for deducting the penalty in the tender conditions and contract conditions; so that the penalty covers all aspects of deficiency or delay in execution, and that it is graduated in application in proportion to the degree of violation, whether by a lump sum or by a specific percentage of the value of the item that is deficient in its execution or by any other method that is consistent with the nature of the item that is deficient in its execution.
summary: This article mandates the governmental entity to specify the method for deducting penalties in contracts, considering the degree of violation.

content: In addition to deducting the penalty, the value of the unexecuted items and services or those executed contrary to what was agreed upon, regardless of their value, shall be deducted, considering them as unexecuted items.
summary: This article mandates deducting the value of unexecuted items and services in addition to the penalty.

content: In general construction contracts, if the governmental entity –after the preliminary handover– finds that the delayed portion does not prevent benefiting from the work completely on the date specified for its completion and does not cause any disruption in using any other benefit and does not negatively affect what has been done from the work itself, the deduction of the penalty shall be limited to the value of the delayed works, in accordance with the method of estimating the penalty on the original works, provided that the total penalty does not exceed (20%) of the value of the delayed works.
summary: This article specifies the method for deducting penalties in construction contracts if the delayed portion does not prevent benefiting from the work.

content:
1- In mixed contracts, if the contractor is deficient or late in executing his obligations, the penalty shall be applied to each part according to its nature, and not exceeding the upper limit of the penalty percentage stipulated pursuant to the system; provided that the contract parts are separate, in terms of execution period, delivery, and total value.
2- If the contract parts are not separate, the penalty shall be applied in accordance with the dominant activity.
summary: This article specifies the method for applying penalties in mixed contracts, depending on whether contract parts are separate.

content: The contractor must execute the contract within the specified period and in accordance with the time schedule approved by the governmental entity, and the entity is not permitted to issue a decision to extend the contract or notify the contractor of extending his contract except in the cases specified pursuant to Article (seventy-four) of the system, and granting the contractor an opportunity to complete the works and amend the time schedule shall not be considered an extension exempt from the penalty.
summary: This article mandates the contractor to execute the contract within the specified period, prohibiting extension except in specified cases.

chapter.name: Contract Extension, Penalty Exemption, and Work Suspension

content:
1- Orders to stop contractors from all or part of the works shall be issued by the authorized person for the award, provided that the order issued to stop work is simultaneous with the actual suspension period, and that the contractor is notified thereof pursuant to a letter specifying the date of commencement of stopping the works or part thereof, and he must also be notified of the resumption of works after the reasons for the suspension cease.
2- The contractor shall be compensated for the entire period of the total suspension by a similar period. If the suspension is partial, he shall be compensated for a period proportionate to the effect of the suspended portion on the progress of the project based on a technical report prepared by the consultant (if any).
3- The contractor shall be compensated for every (thirty) consecutive days of total suspension by a period of (three) days; for preparing and getting ready to resume work, provided that the total compensation periods do not exceed (forty-five) days.
4- If the contractor is commissioned to execute additional works, the execution of the contract shall be extended for a period proportionate to the volume of additional works commissioned to the contractor.
summary: This article specifies work suspension procedures, compensation for the suspension period, and contract extension in the event of additional works.

chapter.name: Contract Extension, Penalty Exemption, and Work Suspension

content:
Except in cases of extension due to suspension, commissioning additional works, or a deficiency in the financial appropriation, the governmental entity shall extend the contract in accordance with the following procedures:
1- After receiving the extension request from the contractor, the consultant shall prepare a technical report on the reasons and justifications that necessitate the extension, and submit his report to the governmental entity within (twenty-one) days from the date of receiving the request. If the project does not require a consultant, the contractor shall submit the extension request directly to the governmental entity, stating the reasons and justifications for the extension.
2- The governmental entity shall study the extension request technically and prepare a report on the extension period, and submit it to the bid examination committee to study it and prepare the appropriate recommendation for the authorized person, provided that the committee’s minutes shall include the reasons and justifications for the extension, within a period not exceeding (thirty) days.
3- After the approval of the authorized person, the contractor shall be notified of the extension, and a copy shall be sent to the consultant to amend the time schedule within (seven) days. If there is no project consultant, the contractor shall amend the time schedule within the period specified in this paragraph and in accordance with what the authorized person approves.
4- The extension period must be proportionate to the circumstances necessitating the extension.
summary: This article specifies contract extension procedures in cases not related to suspension or additional works, detailing the roles of the consultant and bid examination committee.

chapter.name: Contract Extension, Penalty Exemption, and Work Suspension

content:
1- If the contract period in general construction contracts expires and the contractor has not handed over the works, the governmental entity shall form a technical committee to inspect the works and prepare minutes jointly with the contractor; to list the completed works, the completion percentage, and determine the reasons and obstacles for the delay in execution.
2- Works in general construction contracts shall be received on a preliminary basis after the contractor submits a notification of their completion, and the governmental entity shall form a committee to commence inspection and receipt within (fifteen) days from the date of receiving the contractor’s notification. If the entity is unable to receive the project for reasons unrelated to the contractor –such as the existence of something preventing operation or testing or for another reason that is the responsibility of the entity–, minutes of inspection shall be prepared with the participation of the contractor or his representative to list all the works completed in the project.
summary: This article specifies work handover procedures in general construction contracts, with the formation of a technical committee for inspection, and preparing minutes.

content:
1- Without prejudice to the provisions of Article (one hundred and twenty-four) of these bylaws, the project in general construction contracts shall remain under the contractor’s guarantee for a period of not less than (one) year, from the date of the preliminary handover, and if there are deficiencies in the project after its handover, the guarantee period for those deficiencies shall commence from the date of their handover.
2- During the guarantee year referred to in paragraph (1) of this article, the contractor shall be committed to maintaining, repairing, and replacing any defects that appear in the materials, devices, or equipment or defects in execution, and the entity’s receipt of the works without expressing its remarks thereon or on any deficiencies or materials that violate the specifications that have not been addressed during the preliminary handover shall not prevent the contractor’s commitment to guaranteeing and maintaining them. If he does not adhere to this, the works shall be executed at his expense for an amount not exceeding the prevailing prices, after notifying him in the manner deemed appropriate by the entity.
3- The guarantee and maintenance referred to in paragraph (2) of this article do not include periodic or regular maintenance resulting from use, unless the reason is due to a defect in the materials, devices, or equipment or in execution, according to technical standards.
4- Works in general construction contracts shall be received on a final basis after the expiry of the guarantee and maintenance period and the contractor executing his obligations and handing over the plans, specifications of devices and equipment, and documents related to the project in accordance with the contract conditions.
summary: This article specifies the project guarantee period in construction contracts, the contractor's maintenance and repair obligations, and final handover procedures.

content:
1- In continuous execution contracts, the governmental entity shall form a technical committee to inspect and receive the works before the expiry of the contract period by (thirty) days, and those works shall be received pursuant to minutes signed by the contractor or his representative. The contractor shall be committed to completing any deficiency or shortfall in the works, and if he does not adhere to this, those works shall be executed at his expense for an amount not exceeding the prevailing prices or by deducting their value from the contractor’s statements, after notifying him in the manner deemed appropriate by the entity.
2- Works shall be received on a final basis after the expiry of the contract period in accordance with the mechanism and procedures referred to in paragraph (1) of this article.
summary: This article specifies work handover procedures in continuous execution contracts.

content:
1- Taking into account the rules and procedures of government warehouses, the supplier shall deliver the items to the governmental entity’s warehouses or to the place specified for delivery in the contract.
2- The entity shall receive items that require inspection on a temporary basis, and a temporary receipt notice shall be prepared clarifying what has been supplied, and the date of temporary receipt of the items, if accepted, shall be considered the final receipt date.
3- The supplier shall be notified of the date of the inspection and receipt committee meeting, and he shall be permitted to attend the final inspection and receipt procedures. The committee’s decision to accept or reject the items shall be considered valid once it is approved by the authorized person.
4- If the inspection committee rejects one or more of the supplied items, the supplier shall be notified of the rejected items and the reasons for their rejection and the need to withdraw them within (seven) days and supply replacements within a period determined by the inspection committee, and the entity shall not bear responsibility for any loss or damage to the items after the expiry of the period specified for their withdrawal.
5- If the supplier requests re-analysis of the rejected items for not conforming to the specifications or the approved sample and his request is accepted, the supplier shall bear the analysis costs unless the result is in his favor.
summary: This article specifies item delivery and receipt procedures, with the role of the inspection committee, and rejection and re-analysis procedures.

content:
1- If the contractor breaches one or more parts of the project, the governmental entity shall notify him to rectify his situation within (fifteen) days. If the contractor does not comply, the entity may execute this part at his expense for an amount not exceeding the prevailing prices.
2- Partial withdrawal from the contractor shall be by decision of the head of the governmental entity or his delegate, based on a recommendation from the bid examination committee or the committee responsible for purchasing, as the case may be, and the contractor shall be notified thereof.
summary: This article specifies partial withdrawal procedures from the contractor in case of breaching part of the project.

content: The governmental entity shall place a lien on the dues of the contractor from whom the works have been withdrawn for an amount not exceeding the value of the works that will be executed at his expense, until the cost of those works is paid either directly or by deduction from his dues.
summary: This article mandates placing a lien on the dues of the contractor from whom works have been withdrawn.

content: If the entity decides to execute the partially withdrawn works at the contractor’s expense, the execution must be in accordance with the terms and specifications contracted with the contractor from whom the works have been withdrawn.
summary: This article mandates executing withdrawn works according to the original contract terms.

content: The governmental entity may immediately execute at the contractor’s expense the works in which he was deficient if those works represent one or more items of the contract with the contractor continuing to execute the remaining works, or were among the remaining works after the preliminary handover, or were among the final handover remarks that the contractor must rectify, or the contract is among continuous execution contracts that cannot tolerate delay. This shall be done by issuing a limited invitation among the tender applicants in accordance with the provisions of the system and these bylaws; provided that the invitation is directed to all bidders whose bids followed the winning bid in order and their number shall not be less than (three), or that those works are floated in a new tender.
summary: This article permits immediate execution at the contractor's expense in specific cases, with a limited invitation or a new tender.

content:
1- Taking into account the provisions of Articles (seventy-six) and (seventy-seven) of the system, the contract shall be terminated by decision of the authorized person based on a recommendation from the bid examination committee or the committee responsible for purchasing, as the case may be, and the contractor shall be notified thereof in accordance with Article (ninety) of these bylaws.
2- When terminating the contract, the governmental entity shall place a lien on the contractor’s dues to cover all its rights against the contractor, until the final accounting of the project works is carried out.
3- Taking into account the provisions of Article (seventy-six) of the system, if the governmental entity deems that it is in the best interest of the project to continue executing the works without interruption, it may suspend the termination decision and manage the project itself or through a consultant at the contractor’s expense.
4- If a limited tender is carried out among the bidders whose bids followed the winning bid in accordance with the provisions of paragraph (3) of Article (seventy-six) of the system, the invitation must be directed to all bidders whose bids followed the winning bid in order, and their number shall not be less than (three).
summary: This article specifies contract termination procedures, with the possibility of suspending the termination decision or carrying out a limited tender.

content: Terminating the contract by the governmental entity merely because it wishes to execute the works itself or through another contractor shall not be considered among the reasons for the public interest. In the event of terminating the contract for reasons of public interest, the entity shall be committed to notifying the contractor thereof, and the termination shall not be considered valid in this case until (thirty) days have passed from the date of notification.
summary: This article prohibits contract termination merely at the governmental entity's wish, requiring notification thirty days prior to termination.

content:
The governmental entity may terminate the contract by agreement between it and the contractor in the following cases:
1- If the governmental entity is late in handing over the work site to the contractor for a period exceeding the period specified in paragraph (2) of Article (fifty-nine) of the system, and after notifying the contractor of this by the governmental entity, and (thirty) days pass from the date of notification without it handing over the site or taking any acceptable procedures in this regard. The governmental entity’s inability to hand over parts of the site shall not be considered as what is subject to the provision of this article as long as the contractor can work on the other parts.
2- If the governmental entity continues to suspend all works for reasons unrelated to the contractor for a period exceeding (one hundred and eighty) days from the date of the letter ordering the suspension of works, and after notifying the contractor by the governmental entity to enable him to resume works, and (thirty) days pass from the date of notification without it enabling the contractor to resume works or taking any acceptable procedures in this regard.
3- If executing the works becomes impossible due to force majeure, taking into account the notification requirements and the time limit necessary for the permissibility of termination stipulated in the contract.
summary: This article specifies contract termination cases by agreement, including late site handover, work suspension, and force majeure.

content:
Upon contract termination, the contractor must do the following:
1- Stop executing works immediately, unless the consultant directs otherwise to protect persons or property or to ensure the safety of the executed works.
2- Hand over all project documents, machinery equipment, materials, and other works at the site to the governmental entity; which are considered its property.
3- Remove all other supplies from the site, except for what is required for safety matters.
summary: This article specifies the contractor's obligations upon contract termination.

content:
1- After the notification of contract termination becomes valid, the governmental entity must do the following:
A- Account with the contractor for the works that have been executed at the site, and recover from him the remaining balance of the advance payment, if any.
B- Pay the contractor the value of the supplies and materials at the site, that were approved before the date of notification of termination of works. It shall also pay him the value of the materials and supplies that he had previously purchased and imported for the contract and have not been brought to the site; provided that the contractor presents proof of their purchase for the purpose of executing the contract works and hands them over to the governmental entity. All supplies and materials that have been supplied and whose value has been paid by the governmental entity shall be considered its property.
2- When terminating the contract in accordance with the provisions of Article (seventy-seven) of the system, the governmental entity must release the advance payment guarantee and the final guarantee, after carrying out the necessary settlements.
summary: This article specifies the governmental entity's obligations upon contract termination.

content:
1- The contractor’s performance shall be evaluated according to the type of contract, as follows:
A- Taking into account the provisions of paragraph (3) of Article (fifty-six) of the system, the evaluation in continuous execution contracts shall be periodic as clarified by the performance level conditions in the contract, in addition to carrying out the final evaluation after executing the contract.
B- In immediate supply contracts, the final evaluation shall be at the end of the contract and after receiving the works.
C- In framework agreements, each purchase order from the governmental entity shall be evaluated, in addition to the final evaluation of the contractor’s overall performance in the agreement.
2- The governmental entity shall stipulate in the contract the time schedules for carrying out the evaluation processes for the contractor according to the type of evaluation.
3- The governmental entity shall adhere to the evaluation criteria contained in the form prepared by the Center for Achieving Spending Efficiency.
4- The governmental entity shall notify the contractor of the evaluation result, and upload it to the portal to be recorded in his record after the evaluation result becomes final. Other governmental entities have access to it.
5- If the contractor repeatedly obtains a score of less than (70%) in the performance level for three consecutive contracts, he shall be referred to the committee stipulated in Article (eighty-eight) of the system to consider prohibiting dealings with him.
summary: This article specifies the method for evaluating contractor performance according to contract type, with evaluation procedures and results.

content: Taking into account the rules and procedures of government warehouses, the governmental entity shall form a committee of not less than three specialists, responsible for estimating the value of the items and movables to be sold; provided that the condition of the items, their cost, their useful life, and other factors affecting the price estimation shall be taken into account, and a pricing entity with expertise in the field of the items to be sold may be used if the governmental entity does not have sufficient expertise.
summary: This article mandates forming a committee to estimate the value of items and movables to be sold.

content: Estimated prices shall be placed in a sealed envelope that shall only be opened by the chairman of the sale committee in the presence of its members, after opening the auction envelopes or the end of the public auction.
summary: This article specifies the method for placing estimated prices in a sealed envelope.

content:
1- The governmental entity shall form a committee of not less than three members, for the purpose of conducting the public auction and opening envelopes and examining bids for the items to be sold in the auction using sealed envelopes.
2- The committee shall verify the integrity of the envelopes, auction documents, and guarantees submitted, and shall review the bid prices and announce them to those present from among the bidders or their representatives.
3- The committee shall complete the auction procedures, and determine the best bids that conform to the auction conditions, and submit its minutes to the authorized person for approval of the award.
4- If the auction is public, after the end of the auction, the committee shall prepare minutes clarifying the auction procedures, the price of the successful bidder, and the guarantee submitted by him, and submit its minutes to the authorized person for approval of the award.
summary: This article specifies the formation of an auction committee, bid examination procedures, and determining the best bids.

content: If the auction prices fall below the estimated prices by more than (15%), they shall be announced again after re-estimating them, and if a suitable price is not obtained, they may be sold or granted in accordance with the provisions of Article (eighty-three) of the system.
summary: This article mandates re-announcing the auction if prices fall below estimated prices by more than 15%.

content: If the items or movables are of a type that deteriorates quickly in storage, they may be sold in accordance with the provisions of Article (eighty-one) of the system.
summary: This article permits selling quickly deteriorating items according to Article 81.

content: The award of the auction must be decided within a period not exceeding (thirty) days from the date of opening the auction envelopes or the end of the public auction, and if this period passes without deciding on the auction, the bidder may withdraw his bid and recover his guarantee, pursuant to a letter he submits to the entity within (ten) days of the expiry of the period specified for deciding on the award, and those who do not submit their letters within this period shall be considered as agreeing to continue their bids.
