summary: This article specifies the period for deciding on the auction award, and the possibility of bid withdrawal.

content: The bidder awarded the auction must increase his guarantee to (5%) of the value of his bid, and he shall be given a period not exceeding (ten) days from the date of notifying him of the award to pay the full value of the movables and their transportation costs, and he shall be notified –in writing– in the event of his delay in payment. If he does not pay within (fifteen) days from the date of his notification, his guarantee shall be confiscated and negotiations shall be conducted with other bidders –in order– to reach the price of the successful bidder, and if this price is not reached, it shall be floated again.
summary: This article specifies the obligations of the winning bidder, including increasing the guarantee, payment, and guarantee confiscation procedures in case of delay.

content: The purchaser shall be committed to transporting what he has purchased within a period not exceeding (fifteen) days from the date of paying the value of the sold items and movables. If he is late, he shall be notified –in writing– to transport them within a similar period. If he does not transport them, his guarantee shall not be released until they are transported, in accordance with paragraph (2) of Article (eighty-two) of the system, with the possibility of recourse against him for storage fees. The governmental entity shall not bear responsibility for any loss or damage to the sold items and movables after the expiry of the period specified for their transportation.
summary: This article mandates the purchaser to transport purchases within a specified period, with guarantee recovery procedures in case of delay.

content: Licensed brokers may be used to conduct the public auction in exchange for a commission paid by the purchaser not exceeding (2.5%) of the value of sales, and brokers shall be chosen in accordance with the provisions of the system and these bylaws.
summary: This article permits using licensed brokers for the public auction.

content:
If the governmental entity wishes to secure some of its needs by leasing such as equipment, cars, and computer devices and programs; it shall take into account the following controls:
1- That the lease achieves a benefit for the governmental entity that exceeds the benefit achieved from purchasing.
2- That the estimation of the need for leasing shall be based on a technical report prepared by a specialized technical committee, and approved by the authorized person for the award.
3- That the leased devices or supplies are insured by the lessor or are under his guarantee for the duration of the lease, with his commitment in all cases to maintaining them during the lease period.
4- The lease period must be proportionate to the approved cost of the contract in the budget, provided that it does not exceed (five) years.
summary: This article specifies the controls for leasing equipment and devices, including that leasing achieves a greater benefit than purchasing.

content:
If the governmental entity wishes to replace its devices or equipment with new ones –paying the difference in value– it shall take into account the following controls:
1- Expiry of the useful life of the devices, or that they are among devices that are constantly being updated and developed, or that do not meet the entity’s needs, or that the cost of maintenance and spare parts is high compared to the cost of new devices and their maintenance.
2- That the replacement achieves savings for the public treasury better than selling.
3- That the governmental entity shall form a technical committee to inspect the old devices, and prepare a technical report thereon specifying their purchase date, their insured cost, their current condition, and their estimated value, and that the technical committee shall clarify in the report its verification of what is mentioned in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this article.
4- The terms and specifications of the new devices offered for competition shall include the estimated value of the old devices, and the competition shall be in the value of the new devices.
5- That the allocated item at the entity permits deducting the full cost of the new asset.
6- The total cost of the new asset shall be deducted from the allocated appropriation, and the value of the old asset shall be recorded as revenue as government sales, and the old asset shall be disbursed to the supplier with the difference in value.
summary: This article specifies the controls for replacing devices and equipment with new ones, requiring savings, and forming a technical committee.

chapter.name: Replacing Devices and Equipment with New Ones

content: The governmental entity’s needs that are secured by leasing or by replacing its devices and equipment with new ones shall be floated in a public tender, and it may be secured by a limited tender or direct purchase in accordance with the provisions of the system and these bylaws.
summary: This article mandates floating leasing or replacement needs in a public tender, with the possibility of using other methods.

chapter.name: Replacing Devices and Equipment with New Ones

content:
Taking into account the provisions of paragraph (4) of Article (eighty-six) of the system, the following provisions shall apply:
1- A guarantee shall be submitted when objecting before the committee referred to in Article (eighty-six) of the system.
2- An objection shall not be accepted if the guarantee is not submitted or is incomplete.
3- The guarantee shall be valid for a period of not less than (thirty) days from the date of submitting the objection.
4- The objector is not required to renew the guarantee validity period if it expires without deciding on the objection.
summary: This article specifies the conditions for submitting an objection, including submitting a guarantee.

content:
Firstly: Taking into account the provisions of paragraph (2) of Article (ninety-two) of the system, the following are required for agreeing to arbitration:
• Arbitration shall be limited to contracts whose estimated value exceeds one hundred million riyals, and the minister may amend this limit as he deems appropriate.
• Arbitration shall be within the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia at the Saudi Center for Commercial Arbitration or at one of the licensed arbitration centers, and the laws of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia shall apply to the subject matter of the dispute. Arbitration with international arbitration bodies outside the Kingdom and the application of their procedures is not permissible.
• Arbitration and its conditions shall be stipulated in the contract documents.
• Contracts whose place of execution is outside the Kingdom are exempt from the provision of paragraph (1) of this article; so that it is permissible to agree to arbitration –after obtaining the approval of the minister or his delegate– regardless of the estimated value of the contract.
Secondly: If recourse is made to arbitration, the governmental entity shall be committed to providing the ministry and the General Auditing Bureau with a copy of the final decision issued on the subject matter of the arbitration.
summary: This article specifies the conditions for agreeing to arbitration, requiring arbitration within the Kingdom.

content:
In the event of a technical dispute between the governmental entity and the contractor, and it may lead to the project being stalled or causing damage to the client, the contractor, or any of the state’s facilities, the governmental entity shall resolve the dispute amicably. If it is unable to do so, the dispute shall be resolved through a dispute resolution council in accordance with the following procedures:
1- The council shall be formed of a team that includes in its membership a representative of the governmental entity and a representative of the contractor, and the ministry shall appoint the chairman of the council from the governmental or private sector.
2- The chairman and members of the council must have experience and competence in the field of the dispute.
3- Each party to the dispute shall submit to the council a technical report on the subject matter of the dispute, including its point of view and documents related to the subject matter of the dispute, and the consultant supervising the execution of the works –if any– shall submit a report including his point of view on the dispute. The council may inspect the works in kind and enter the site.
4- The council may request the opinion and advice of an expert entity if it finds that resolving the dispute requires resorting to this, and the cost thereof shall be shared equally between the parties to the dispute.
5- The council must decide on the dispute within (thirty) days from the date of receiving the report and related documents.
6- The council shall issue its decision by majority vote, clarifying the dissenting opinion, if any, and if both parties to the dispute agree to the council’s decision, the decision shall be final on the subject matter of the dispute, but if either of them objects to the decision, it shall be returned to the council clarifying the opinion subject to objection, and the council shall decide thereon within (fifteen) days, and the council’s decision shall then be binding, and the aggrieved party has the right to resort to the competent judicial authority.
7- The ministry shall specify the rewards and fees of the council chairman and representatives of the governmental entity, and shall pay them.
8- Considering any dispute between the parties must not prevent the contractor from continuing to execute his obligations.
9- Resolving the dispute through the council is limited to technical disputes between the governmental entity and the contractor, excluding other claims.
summary: This article specifies technical dispute resolution procedures, including forming a dispute resolution council, its procedures, and the possibility of resorting to the judicial authority.

content: Taking into account the provisions of these bylaws, the General Authority for Military Industries shall issue the rules governing the works and tasks referred to in Article (fourteen) and paragraph (1) of Article (thirty-two) of the system.
summary: This article mandates the General Authority for Military Industries to issue rules governing the specified works and tasks.

content: These bylaws shall be published in the official gazette, and shall apply from the date of the system’s enforcement, and shall be reviewed after (two) years from the date of their application.
summary: This article stipulates publishing the bylaws in the official gazette, their enforcement date, and review after two years.

content: The following expressions and terms, wherever they appear in this system, shall have the meanings explained opposite each of them, unless the context requires otherwise: System: The Government Competition and Procurement System. Regulation: The Executive Regulation of the System. Minister: Minister of Finance. Ministry: Ministry of Finance. Authority: The Authority for Local Content and Government Procurement. Entity responsible for unified procurement: The entity responsible for unified strategic procurement, to be determined by a decision of the Council of Ministers. Government entities: Ministries, government bodies, authorities, departments, public institutions, and independent public bodies with legal personality. Head of the government entity: The Minister, President, Governor, or the most senior official in the government entity. Portal: A unified electronic portal for government procurement under the supervision of the Ministry. Framework agreement: An agreement between one or more government entities and one or more suppliers, contractors, or subcontractors, including the terms and conditions of contracts to be awarded during a specific period. Reverse electronic auction: An electronic method for submitting successively reduced bids within a specified period, with the aim of selecting the lowest bid. Consultancy services: Services of a professional or consultancy nature, including, but not limited to, the preparation of studies and research, the development of specifications, plans, and designs, and supervision of their implementation, such as the services of accountants and lawyers. Prior qualification: The government entity verifies the availability of the necessary qualifications and capabilities to execute work and secure purchases from competitors before they submit their bids. Subsequent qualification: The government entity verifies, after selecting the best bid, the availability of the necessary qualifications and capabilities from the bidder to execute the work and secure purchases before awarding the contract. Stop period: A period that begins on the date of notifying the competitors of the winning bid in order to consider any complaints they submit. Emergency situation: A situation in which there is a serious and unexpected threat to public safety, security, or public health, or in which there is a breach that threatens loss of life or property, and cannot be dealt with using normal competition procedures. Urgent situation: A situation in which the execution of work or the securing of purchases in a short time is essential and necessary to ensure the safety and adequacy of the workflow in the government entity.
summary: Definition of key terms and concepts used in the system.

content: The system aims to achieve the following: 1- Regulating procedures related to works and purchases, and preventing the exploitation of influence and the impact of personal interests; thus protecting public funds. 2- Achieving the best value for public funds when contracting for works and purchases and implementing them at fair competitive prices. 3- Enhancing integrity and competition, achieving equality, and providing fair treatment to competitors; in pursuit of the principle of equal opportunities. 4- Ensuring transparency in all procedures for works and purchases. 5- Promoting economic development.
summary: The main objectives of the system are to protect public funds, ensure integrity and transparency, promote fair competition, and enhance economic development.

content: 1- Government entities, when executing their work and securing their purchases, shall deal with persons licensed to do so, in accordance with the applicable regulations and rules. 2- When dealing with foreign persons to secure purchases or execute work within the Kingdom, the government entity shall ensure that there is no more than one qualified local person to secure the required purchases or execute the work. The regulation shall specify the necessary conditions and controls for applying the provisions of this paragraph.
summary: Conditions for government entities dealing with local and foreign contractors, and priority given to qualified local persons.

content: All persons wishing to deal with the government entity, who meet the conditions that qualify them for this dealing, shall be given equal opportunities and treated equally.
summary: Equal opportunities and equal treatment for those wishing to contract with government entities.

content: Competitors shall be provided with clear and unified information about the required works and purchases, and they shall be enabled to obtain it at a specified time.
summary: Providing clear and unified information to competitors at a specific time.

content: Public competition shall be subject to the principles of publicity, transparency, and equal opportunities.
summary: Public competition is subject to the principles of publicity, transparency, and equal opportunities.

content: Bids shall not be accepted and contracts concluded on the basis thereof except in accordance with the provisions of the system.
summary: Bids shall only be accepted in accordance with the provisions of the system.

content: The tendering of works and purchases and the conclusion of contracts shall be within the limits of the actual needs of the government entity, and at fair prices not exceeding the prevailing market prices.
summary: Tendering of works and purchases within actual needs and at fair prices.

content: Priority shall be given to dealing with small and medium-sized local enterprises and local content, and companies listed on the financial market. The regulation referred to in paragraph (3) of Article (ninety-six) of the system shall explain the mechanism thereof.
summary: Priority given to dealing with small and medium-sized local enterprises, local content, and listed companies.

content: The system shall apply to all government entities.
summary: Application of the system to all government entities.

chapter.name: Scope of Application of the System

content: Works and purchases executed outside the Kingdom shall be subject to the provisions of the system, and it is permissible to exempt them from some of these provisions as explained in the regulation.
keywords: Works and purchases outside the Kingdom
summary: Works and purchases executed outside the Kingdom are subject to the system, with the possibility of exemptions.

chapter.name: Scope of Application of the System

content: 1- The government entity shall plan its work and purchases in advance and coordinate with the ministry in providing financial allocations for it, and shall be committed at the beginning of each fiscal year to publishing a plan consistent with its budget that includes the main information about its work and purchases during this year, without prejudice to what national security requires in terms of confidentiality. 2- The publication of the government entity’s plans for its work and purchases shall not entail any obligation.
summary: Prior planning for works and purchases and publishing an annual plan.

content: 1- In implementation of the provisions of the system; the ministry shall do the following: a- Establish the portal, supervise it, and develop it continuously. b- Develop policies, and issue guidelines, instructions, and guidance manuals related to the implementation of the provisions of the system and regulation. c- Collect information related to competition activities, publish it on the portal, and follow up on the implementation of the provisions of the system, without prejudice to the roles of other oversight bodies. d- Publish lists of persons prohibited from dealing with, through the portal. 2- The minister shall approve the models of competition documents, prior qualification documents, contract models, models for evaluating the performance of contractors, and any other document required by the nature of the work or purchases.
summary: The ministry’s tasks in establishing and managing the portal, developing policies, and publishing information.

content: Without prejudice to the competence of the General Authority for Military Industries, and in implementation of the provisions of the system; the entity responsible for unified procurement shall be responsible for the following: 1- Determining the works and purchases needed by more than one government entity, unifying their technical specifications, directly undertaking all procedures for their tendering, receiving, studying, and selecting the best bids, and concluding framework agreements on their behalf on behalf of government entities in accordance with the provisions of the system. 2- Preparing lists of works and purchases for which framework agreements have been concluded, and enabling government entities to access them and the clauses contained in the framework agreements through the portal. 3- Reviewing feasibility studies and estimated costs submitted to it by government entities for purchases and works that it undertakes to tender, and related competition documents and prior qualification documents - if any - and expressing its opinion thereon within a period determined by the regulation. 4- Preparing models of competition documents and prior qualification documents, contract models, models for evaluating the performance of contractors, and any other document required by the nature of the work or purchases; in accordance with the provisions of the system, regulation, and regulations stipulated in Article (ninety-six) of the system. 5- Preparing the necessary training programs to develop the qualifications and skills of those responsible for implementing the provisions of the system in government entities.
summary: The responsibilities of the entity responsible for unified procurement in unifying purchases, reviewing studies, and preparing training programs.

content: 1- It shall not be permissible for the government entity to secure purchases or execute works listed in the lists prepared by the entity responsible for unified procurement except through the framework agreements concluded by the entity responsible for unified procurement. 2- As an exception to the provisions of paragraph (1) of this article, the government entity may, after the approval of the entity responsible for unified procurement, execute works and secure purchases listed in the lists in accordance with the provisions of the system. 3- Before tendering its projects or work or before conducting prior qualification - if any - the government entity shall submit a feasibility study and estimated cost, competition documents, and prior qualification documents - if any - and the procedures it has taken, to the entity responsible for unified procurement; for review within the period determined by the regulation, and if the entity responsible for unified procurement does not respond within this period, it shall be deemed approval, and the government entity shall abide by any amendments requested by the entity responsible for unified procurement. 4- As an exception to the provisions of paragraph (3) of this article, the government entity may tender its projects or work or conduct prior qualification - if any - without submitting a feasibility study and estimated cost, competition documents, and prior qualification documents - if any - and the procedures it has taken, to the entity responsible for unified procurement; this applies to works and purchases whose estimated cost does not exceed the amount determined by the regulation or those involving an emergency or urgent situation, and it is sufficient to notify the entity responsible for unified procurement of what has been done in this regard.
summary: Regulation of the relationship between government entities and the entity responsible for unified procurement, with exceptions.

content: Government competition and procurement procedures shall be tendered through the portal - unless this is impossible for technical reasons or reasons related to national security - in accordance with what the regulation explains.
summary: Tendering government competition and procurement procedures through the electronic portal.

content: 1- The portal must have the highest degrees of privacy, confidentiality, security, and transparency of information, while ensuring the integrity of procedures. 2- The portal must allow those interested and concerned to access information and data related to the competitions specified by the regulation. 3- A register shall be allocated in the portal for each government entity in which all information, data, and procedures related to the contracts it has concluded and the projects and works it has tendered shall be recorded, in accordance with what the regulation explains. 4- The ministry shall charge a financial fee for the services provided by the portal, and the Council of Ministers shall determine the amount of this fee, and it may be amended by a decision of the council based on a proposal from the ministry.
summary: Requirements for the electronic portal in terms of privacy, security, and transparency of information.

content: The persons with whom government entities deal must meet the conditions necessary to execute work and secure purchases in accordance with what the regulation explains.
summary: Determining the necessary conditions for contractors with government entities.

chapter.name: Conditions for Dealing and Qualifying Competitors

content: 1- The government entity shall conduct prior or subsequent qualification in works and purchases in accordance with what the regulation explains. 2- In the event of prior qualification, the invitation to participate in the competition shall be limited to those who have passed the prior qualification only.
summary: Conducting prior or subsequent qualification for competitors.

chapter.name: Conditions for Dealing and Qualifying Competitors

content: The criteria for prior or subsequent qualification must be objective, measurable, and related to the technical, financial, and administrative capabilities and the amount of contractual commitments of the competitors, and consistent with the nature, size, and value of the project or work.
summary: Objective and measurable criteria for qualifying competitors.

chapter.name: Conditions for Dealing and Qualifying Competitors

content: 1- Competition documents must include information and data related to the tendered works and purchases in accordance with what the regulation specifies. 2- Electronic copies of the competition documents must be provided on the portal. If this is not possible for technical reasons, sufficient paper copies shall be provided. 3- The regulation shall determine the criteria for determining the costs of competition documents.
summary: Requirements for competition documents and their provision electronically or in paper form.

content: 1- The technical terms and specifications for the tendered works and purchases must be detailed, accurate, and clear, and must take into account the approved standard specifications or international specifications for anything that does not have approved national specifications, and must not include reference to a specific type or category, or specify a specific trademark or trade name, or set specifications that only apply to specific contractors, producers, or suppliers. 2- As an exception to the provisions of paragraph (1) of this article, it is permissible to refer to a specific trademark or trade name in cases where it is impossible to accurately describe and specify the technical specifications, provided that prior approval is obtained from the entity responsible for unified procurement and that the competition documents include the phrase “and its equivalent”. 3- The government entity shall not exaggerate in the technical specifications, and they shall not exceed the needs and requirements of the project and the financial allocations allocated to it. 4- The government entity may consult with those it deems appropriate to consult with from experts and specialists when developing technical specifications. 5- When developing technical specifications, the government entity shall take into account the requirements and needs of persons with disabilities.
summary: Requirements for technical terms and specifications, taking into account standard specifications and the needs of persons with disabilities.

content: Before setting the estimated cost for works and purchases, the government entity shall do the following: 1- Accurately study market prices, and take into account the setting of an upper limit for the expected total value of the contract. 2- Set the necessary controls to maintain the confidentiality of the estimated cost.
summary: Studying market prices to determine the estimated cost while maintaining its confidentiality.

content: The government entity shall specify in the competition documents the criteria for evaluating, comparing, and accepting bids in accordance with what the regulation explains.
summary: Specifying criteria for evaluating bids in competition documents.

content: Non-price evaluation criteria must be objective and consistent with the nature of the works and purchases to be tendered, and must be - as far as is practically possible - quantifiable.
summary: Objectivity and measurability of non-price evaluation criteria.

content: It shall not be permissible to divide works and purchases in order to bring them within the scope of direct purchase, limited competition, or the authorities of authorized officials.
summary: Prohibition of dividing works and purchases to fall within the scope of direct purchase or limited competition.

content: It is permissible to accept bids jointly in accordance with what the regulation explains.
summary: Permissibility of accepting joint bids.

content: All works and purchases shall be tendered in public competition except for those exempted therefrom under the provisions of the system.
summary: All works and purchases are tendered in public competition with some exceptions.

content: 1- Public competition shall be announced on the portal, in accordance with what the regulation explains. 2- The regulation shall specify the means of announcing public competition if it is not possible to announce it on the portal for technical reasons.
summary: Announcing public competition through the portal or other means if this is not possible.

content: The government entity may contract using the limited competition method in the following cases: 1- If the works and purchases are only available from a limited number of contractors, suppliers, or subcontractors. 2- If the estimated value of the works and purchases does not exceed (five hundred thousand) riyals, by inviting the largest possible number of competitors, provided that their number is not less than five. In this case, priority shall be given to inviting small and medium-sized local enterprises to negotiate and submit bids. 3- Urgent cases. 4- If the works and purchases are available from non-profit civil society organizations or entities, provided that they themselves undertake what has been contracted for. 5- Consultancy services. The regulation shall specify the necessary controls and procedures for implementing this article.
summary: Conditions for using the limited competition method.

content: The government entity may tender the competition in two phases if it is not possible to fully and accurately determine the final technical specifications and contractual terms; due to the complex and specialized nature of some works and purchases, in accordance with what the regulation explains.
summary: Permissibility of tendering competition in two phases if it is not possible to accurately determine specifications and terms.

content: The government entity may contract using the direct purchase method in the following cases: 1- Securing purchases of weapons, military equipment, and spare parts, through the General Authority for Military Industries. 2- If the works and purchases are exclusively available from one subcontractor, contractor, or supplier, and there is no acceptable alternative, provided that the contract is in accordance with what the regulation determines. 3- If the estimated cost of the works and purchases does not exceed (one hundred thousand) riyals. In this case, priority shall be given to inviting small and medium-sized local enterprises. 4- If the use of this method is necessary to protect national security interests and public competition or limited competition cannot be used. In this case, the government entity shall, after concluding the contract, prepare a report containing the reasons that led it to use this method and provide the General Audit Bureau with a copy thereof. 5- If the works and purchases are available from one non-profit civil society organization or entity, provided that it undertakes what has been contracted for itself. 6- Emergency situations. Without prejudice to the competence of the General Authority for Military Industries as stipulated in paragraph (1) of this article; the regulation shall specify the necessary controls and procedures for implementing what is mentioned in this article.
summary: Cases permitting direct purchase, focusing on national security and emergency situations.

content: The government entity may conclude a framework agreement with the party to whom the competition has been awarded, including the provisions under which the contract will be implemented, in cases where it is not possible to determine the quantities of items, the volume of work or services contracted for, or the date of execution, in accordance with what the regulation explains.
summary: Concluding framework agreements if it is not possible to determine the quantities of items, volume of work, or execution date.

content: The government entity may use the reverse electronic auction method in accordance with what the regulation explains, taking into account the following: 1- That the government entity prepares detailed technical specifications. 2- That there is a competitive market that guarantees effective competition. 3- That bids are received through the portal and sorted automatically. 4- That the start and end dates of the auction are specified. 5- That competitors are provided with the necessary information and instructions for using the portal.
summary: Conditions for using the reverse electronic auction.

content: The authority may, on its own initiative or at the request of a government entity - after the approval of the ministry - contract for industrial localization and knowledge transfer in accordance with the controls determined by the regulation.
summary: Contracting for industrial localization and knowledge transfer.

content: The government entity may contract for the best idea and design, or other intellectual property rights, through a competition method, in accordance with what the regulation explains.
summary: Contracting for the best idea or design through competition.

content: 1- Bids shall be submitted in coded form through the portal, in accordance with what the regulation specifies. 2- Bids shall be submitted by the specified deadline for their acceptance, and it shall not be permissible to accept bids submitted otherwise. 3- It is permissible to accept bids in sealed envelopes if it is not possible to submit them through the portal for technical reasons. 4- The government entity shall announce the names of the persons who submitted their bids through the portal, and if it is not possible to use the portal for technical reasons, it shall announce this by the means specifiedby the regulation.
summary: Method of submitting bids through the portal or alternative methods if this is not possible.

content: The government entity may request the attachment of a sample of the required purchases.
summary: Permissibility of requesting a sample of the required purchases.

content: 1- The validity period of bids in competitions shall be (ninety) days from the date specified for opening bids, and if the bidder withdraws his bid during this period, his initial guarantee shall not be returned to him. 2- The government entity may extend the validity period of bids for another (ninety) days, and any competitor who wishes to continue in the competition shall extend the validity period of his initial guarantee.
summary: Validity period of bids and the possibility of extending it.

content: 1- The total prices and any increase or decrease thereon must be specified in the bid letter, and any reduction submitted by means of a separate letter shall not be considered, even if it is attached to the bid. 2- Except in cases where negotiation is permitted under the provisions of the system, it shall not be permissible for competitors to amend their bid prices upwards or downwards after submission.
summary: Specifying prices in the bid and the prohibition of amending them after submission.

content: 1- The competitor shall submit an initial guarantee with his bid at a rate ranging from (1%) to (2%) of the bid value. The bid that is not submitted with the guarantee shall be excluded. 2- The regulation shall specify the provisions relating to the initial guarantee.
summary: Requirements for submitting the initial guarantee.

content: As an exception to the provisions of Article (forty-one) of the system, it is not necessary to submit the initial guarantee in the following cases: 1- Direct purchase. 2- Competition. 3- Contracts between government entities. 4- Contracting with a non-profit civil society organization or entity. 5- Contracting with small and medium-sized local enterprises.
summary: Exceptions to submitting the initial guarantee.

content: A committee or more shall be formed by a decision of the head of the government entity or his delegate to open bids, in accordance with what the regulation explains.
summary: Forming a committee to open bids.

content: 1- Bids shall be opened in the presence of all members of the committee at the end of the deadline for receiving bids, and a record shall be made thereof, and in cases that require the submission of a technical bid separate from the financial bid, the technical bids shall be opened without the financial bids, and the regulation shall specify the procedures for opening bids. 2- Bidders may attend bid opening sessions. 3- Within (three) days of the date of opening bids, the committee shall refer its record and the bids to the bid examination committee.
summary: Procedures for opening bids and recording a record thereof.

content: 1- A committee or more shall be formed by a decision of the head of the government entity or his delegate to examine bids, in accordance with what the regulation explains. This committee shall examine bids and submit its recommendations on awarding the contract to the best bids, in accordance with the provisions of the system, and it may use reports from specialized technicians in preparing its recommendations. 2- The entity responsible for unified procurement may participate in attending the sessions of the bid examination committee, and shall have the same powers as the other members of the committee. 3- The bid examination committee shall issue its recommendations, and the recommendations shall be recorded in a record with a statement of any dissenting opinion - if any - and the reasons for each opinion, and all the work it has done and the procedures it has taken, and the record shall be submitted to the competent authority to decide on the award in accordance with the provisions of the system. 4- It shall not be permissible to combine the chairmanship of the bid examination committee and the authority to decide on the award, nor shall it be permissible to combine the chairmanship of the bid opening committee and the chairmanship of the bid examination committee or membership in both.
summary: Forming a bid examination committee, its tasks, and submission of its recommendations.

chapter.name: Examining Bids and Contract Award Authority

content: 1- Bids shall be examined in accordance with the criteria stipulated in the competition documents, and non-compliant bids shall be excluded, and the initial guarantees shall be returned to their owners. 2- If bids are submitted in two electronic files or in two sealed envelopes, the technical bids must be examined without the financial bids, and unacceptable technical bids shall be excluded and their financial bids returned unopened with their initial guarantees to their owners. 3- The committee shall examine the financial bids of the accepted technical bids, and submit its recommendations on the best bids, in accordance with the evaluation criteria announced in the competition documents.
summary: Procedures for examining bids and excluding non-compliant bids.

chapter.name: Examining Bids and Contract Award Authority

content: The bid examination committee may negotiate with the holder of the best bid and then with the next competitor in the following two cases: 1- If the price of the best bid is clearly higher than the prevailing market prices, the committee shall determine the amount of the reduction in accordance with those prices, and shall request in writing from its holder to reduce his price, and if he refuses, or if his price does not reach the specified amount, the committee shall negotiate with the holder of the next bid and so on with the rest of the bidders until the specified price is reached, and if it is not reached, the competition shall be canceled. 2- If the value of the best bid exceeds the approved amounts for the project, the committee shall request in writing from its holder to reduce his bid in accordance with the approved amounts, and if he refuses or if his price does not reach the required amount, the committee shall negotiate with the holder of the next bid and so on with the rest of the bidders until a price is reached that is consistent with the approved amounts, and if this is not achieved; the government entity may, after the approval of the entity responsible for unified procurement, cancel or reduce some items to reach the approved amount, provided that this does not affect the benefit of the project or the ranking of bids, and if it is not possible to cancel or reduce some items of the project; the competition shall be canceled.
summary: Permissibility of negotiating with bidders if the price is higher than market price or exceeds approved amounts.

chapter.name: Examining Bids and Contract Award Authority

content: No bid shall be excluded due to low prices unless it is less than (25%) or more than the estimated cost and prevailing market prices, provided that the bid examination committee, after reviewing the estimated prices, shall discuss with the holder of the low bid, and request him in writing to provide details of the elements constituting his bid and explain the reasons for its low price, and if the committee is not convinced of his ability to execute the contract, it may recommend excluding the bid.
summary: Conditions for excluding a bid due to low prices.

chapter.name: Examining Bids and Contract Award Authority

content: The government entity shall announce the results of the competition and notify the other competitors thereof, in accordance with what the regulation explains.
summary: Announcing competition results and notifying competitors.

chapter.name: Examining Bids and Contract Award Authority

content: 1- If only one bid is submitted, or if several bids are submitted and they are found to be non-compliant with the competition documents - except for one bid -, this bid shall not be accepted unless its prices are similar to the prevailing market prices and after the approval of the head of the government entity. 2- The regulation shall specify the necessary provisions in case of equal bids.
summary: Procedures for accepting a single bid or in case of non-compliance of bids with competition documents.

chapter.name: Examining Bids and Contract Award Authority

content: The competition shall be canceled in the following cases: 1- If there are material errors in the competition documents that cannot be remedied. 2- If a procedure is taken that violates the provisions of the system or regulation that cannot be corrected. 3- If there are clear indications that there is fraud or the commission of any acts of corruption, or collusion between competitors or parties related to the competition in a way that prevents the awarding of the competition in accordance with the provisions of the system and regulation. 4- If all bids violate the competition documents. 5- If the public interest so requires.
summary: Cases of canceling the competition.

chapter.name: Examining Bids and Contract Award Authority

content: In the event of cancellation of the competition, the value of the competition documents and the initial guarantees shall be returned to the bidders, in accordance with what the regulation explains.
summary: Returning the value of competition documents and guarantees in case of cancellation.

chapter.name: Examining Bids and Contract Award Authority

content: After the award decision is issued and announced, the government entity shall adhere to a standstill period of not less than (five) working days and not more than (ten) working days; during which the award shall not be approved and the contract signed; in order to enable competitors to appeal the award decision.
summary: A standstill period of no less than five and no more than ten working days before approving the award.

content: 1- The authority to decide on competitions for the execution of works and securing purchases and the assignment of additional works shall be vested in the head of the government entity, and he may delegate this authority in the following two cases: a- Deciding on competitions for the execution of works and securing purchases of no more than (ten million) riyals. b- Assigning additional works of no more than (five million) riyals for each project or (10%) of the project cost; whichever is less. 2- The authority to cancel the competition shall be vested in the head of the government entity, and he may delegate this authority. 3- The authority to terminate contracts shall be vested in the head of the government entity, and he may delegate this authority. 4- The authority to decide on direct purchase shall be vested in the head of the government entity, and he may delegate this authority for no more than (three million) riyals. 5- The authority to decide and award contracts for the sale of movables shall be vested in the head of the government entity, and he may delegate this authority. 6- It shall be ensured that the delegation is gradual according to the responsibility of the delegated person.
keywords: Authorities of the head of the government entity
summary: Authorities of the head of the government entity and delegation in various matters.

content: 1- Contracts and their documents and attachments shall be drafted in Arabic, and it is permissible to use another language in addition to Arabic, provided that Arabic shall be the language used in interpreting, executing, specifying the specifications and plans of the contract, and correspondence related thereto. 2- The government entity may suffice with the exchanged correspondence instead of drafting the contract if the value of the contract does not exceed (three hundred thousand) riyals.
summary: Drafting contracts in Arabic, with the possibility of using another language, and the possibility of using exchanged correspondence.

content: 1- The term of contracts for services with continuous execution, such as maintenance, cleaning, operation, and catering, shall not exceed (five) years, and it may be increased in contracts that require this by their nature; after the approval of the ministry. 2- In all contracts, the period specified for executing the project must be consistent with the size and nature of the work, and with the annual allocations allocated for spending on the project. 3- Contracts for services with continuous execution shall include conditions related to the level of performance and continuous evaluation; so that the government entity may terminate the contract or reduce payments if the performance is not satisfactory, and the regulation shall explain what is required to implement the provisions of this paragraph.
summary: Term of service contracts, consistency of term with the size of the work, and continuous evaluation conditions.

content: The regulation shall specify the types of contracts that government entities may use.
summary: Specifying the permitted types of contracts in the regulation.

content: It is permissible to include clauses in contracts related to transferring knowledge, training, and operating skills to employees of government entities.
summary: Permissibility of including clauses for knowledge transfer and training in contracts.

content: 1- The contract shall be drafted between the government entity and the successful bidder after notifying him of the award decision and submitting the final guarantee letter. 2- The contractor in public construction contracts shall be enabled to commence the execution of the contract within (sixty) days from the date of notification of the award decision, unless the competition documents stipulate otherwise.
summary: Drafting the contract after notifying the winner and submitting the final guarantee, and the commencement of execution period.

content: 1- Government entities shall be obliged to submit their contracts - as specified by the regulation - to the ministry for review before signing them, and the ministry shall review those contracts within (fifteen) working days from the date of their receipt. If the ministry does not respond within this period, it shall be deemed approval. Entities that do not have allocations in the general budget of the state shall be exempted from the provisions of this article. 2- The regulation shall specify the controls for implementing this article.
summary: Obligation to submit contracts to the ministry for review before signing.

content: 1- The party to whom the award is made shall submit a final guarantee of (5%) of the value of the contract, within (fifteen) working days from the date of notification of the award. The government entity may extend this period for a similar period. If he is late, his initial guarantee shall not be returned to him, and negotiation shall be conducted with the next bid, in accordance with the provisions of the system, and it is permissible to increase the percentage of the guarantee after the approval of the minister. 2- If the bidder is from small and medium-sized local enterprises, he shall pay a financial penalty to the government entity equal to the value of the initial guarantee, if he withdraws his bid before the expiry of the bid validity period, or if he does not submit the final guarantee if the award is made to him. If (sixty) days pass from the date of withdrawing his bid, or from the date of expiry of the deadline for submitting the final guarantee without paying the stipulated financial penalty; he shall be punished by being barred from dealing with government entities for one year. 3- It is not necessary to submit the final guarantee in the following cases: a- If the value of the works and purchases does not exceed (one hundred thousand) riyals. b- Contracts between government entities. c- Contracts with a non-profit civil society organization or entity. d- Contracts with companies in which the state owns no less than (51%) of their capital. e- If the contractor has supplied all the items he was awarded to supply, and the government entity has accepted them finally within the period specified for depositing the final guarantee, or has supplied part of them and this part has been accepted and its price is sufficient to cover the value of the final guarantee, provided that what covers the value of the guarantee shall not be disbursed until the contractor has fulfilled his obligation. f- If the contractor is assigned additional works. 4- The final guarantee must be retained until the contractor fulfills his obligations and the project is finally accepted, in accordance with the provisions and conditions of the contract.
summary: Conditions for submitting the final guarantee, exceptions thereto, and penalties for non-submission.

content: The final guarantee in contracts for services with continuous execution shall be reduced annually according to the work completed, provided that the guarantee in all cases shall not be less than (5%) of the value of the remaining work in the contract.
summary: Annual reduction of the final guarantee in service contracts with continuous execution.

content: Guarantees shall be accepted if they are in one of the following forms: 1- A bank guarantee from a local bank. 2- A bank guarantee from a bank outside the Kingdom submitted through a local bank. 3- Any other form specified by the regulation. The regulation shall explain the conditions, provisions, and models of guarantees.
summary: Acceptable forms of guarantees.

content: The value of contracts shall be paid in Saudi riyals, and the government entity may specify another currency or more in the competition documents, provided that this is with the prior approval of the ministry.
summary: Payment of contract value in Saudi riyals, with the possibility of specifying another currency with the ministry’s approval.

content: The total value of the contract shall include all costs of its execution in accordance with its conditions, including the value of fees and taxes paid by the contractor, and it shall not be permissible to exempt therefrom or exempt the profits of contractors with the government entity or the income of their employees from tax or pay it on their behalf, except for what is exempted by a special regulatory text.
summary: Inclusion of all costs in the total contract value, and the prohibition of tax exemption except in exceptional cases.

content: The government entity may pay the contractor an advance payment in return for a bank guarantee equal to this value, in accordance with what the regulation explains.
summary: Permissibility of paying an advance payment in return for a bank guarantee.

content: The dues of the contractor with the government entity shall be disbursed in accordance with what the regulation explains.
summary: Disbursement of contractor’s dues in accordance with the regulation.

content: It shall not be permissible to amend the prices of contracts or framework agreements upwards or downwards except in the following cases: 1- Change in the prices of the main materials or services included in the competition items, as determined by the regulation. 2- Amendment of customs tariffs, fees, or taxes. 3- If material difficulties occur during the execution of the contract that could not have been foreseen. The regulation shall explain the conditions and procedures necessary for applying the provisions of this article.
summary: Cases permitting amendment of contract prices.

content: The government entity may, within the limits of its actual needs, issue change orders to increase the contract by no more than (10%) of its value, and it may issue change orders to reduce it by no more than (20%) of its value, in accordance with what the regulation explains.
summary: Issuing change orders for contracts with specified percentages.

content: The contractor shall not be permitted to assign the contract or part thereof to another contractor, subcontractor, or supplier except after obtaining written approval from the government entity and the ministry, and the regulation shall explain the conditions and controls for assigning the contract or part thereof.
summary: Prohibition of assigning the contract except with the approval of the government entity and the ministry.

content: 1- The contractor shall not be permitted to subcontract with another contractor, subcontractor, or supplier without obtaining written approval from the government entity, and the regulation shall specify the conditions and controls for subcontracting. 2- The government entity may make payments directly to the subcontractor, subcontractor, or supplier, and the regulation shall specify the conditions and controls thereof. 3- In all cases, the contractor shall be jointly and severally liable with the subcontractor, subcontractor, or supplier for the execution of the contract in accordance with its conditions.
summary: Conditions for subcontracting and joint and several liability.

content: If the contractor is late in executing the contract beyond the specified deadline; a delay penalty shall be imposed on him not exceeding (6%) of the value of the supply contract, and not exceeding (20%) of the value of other contracts, and it is permissible to increase these percentages with the prior approval of the minister, provided that this increase is explained to the competitors before submitting their bids.
summary: Delay penalty for contract execution.

content: If the contractor fails to fulfill his obligations in contracts for services with continuous execution; a penalty shall be imposed on him not exceeding (20%) of the value of the contract, with deduction of the value of the work not executed, and it is permissible to increase this percentage with the prior approval of the minister, provided that this increase is explained to the competitors before submitting their bids.
summary: Penalty for contractor’s failure in service contracts with continuous execution.

content: Contract extensions and exemption from the penalty shall be in the following cases: 1- If the contractor is assigned additional works, provided that the added period is proportionate to the size and nature of the work and the date of assignment. 2- If the annual financial allocations for the project are insufficient to complete the work on time. 3- If the delay is due to the government entity or emergency circumstances. 4- If the contractor is late in executing the contract for reasons beyond his control. 5- If the government entity issues an order to stop the work or part thereof for reasons not attributable to the contractor. The regulation shall specify the controls and procedures for extending contracts and exemption from the penalty.
summary: Cases of contract extension and exemption from penalty.

content: The government entity may withdraw part of the works and purchases and execute them at the expense of the contractor; if he violates his contractual obligations after being warned, and the regulation shall explain what is required to implement this article.
summary: Permissibility of withdrawing part of the work and executing it at the contractor’s expense in case of breach of obligations.

chapter.name: Partial Withdrawal and Execution at the Contractor’s Expense

content: 1- The government entity must terminate the contract in the following cases: a- If it is found that the contractor has, himself or through another, directly or indirectly, bribed an employee of the entities subject to the provisions of the system or obtained the contract through bribery, fraud, deception, forgery, manipulation, or practiced any of these during its execution. b- If the contractor becomes bankrupt, or requests the declaration of his bankruptcy, or his insolvency is proven, or an order is issued to place him under guardianship, or if he is a company and it is dissolved or liquidated. c- If the contractor assigns the contract without written approval from the government entity and the ministry. 2- The government entity may terminate the contract in the following cases: a- If the contractor is late in commencing work, or slow in executing it, or violates any condition of the contract and does not rectify his situation within (fifteen) days from the date of notification in writing thereof. b- If the contractor dies. In this case, the contract shall be terminated, dues settled, and guarantees returned. The government entity may continue to contract with the heirs - after their consent - provided that they have the necessary technical qualifications and guarantees to complete the execution of the contract. c- If the contractor subcontracts to execute the contract without written approval from the government entity. 3- In the event of termination of the contract, it is permissible to tender the remaining parts thereof using the same method as the works and purchases were tendered, and the government entity may invite for limited competition among the bidders whose bids followed the winning bid in the ranking, so that they are requested to submit new bids and they are evaluated in accordance with the provisions of the system. 4- The regulation shall specify the conditions and procedures necessary for applying the provisions of this article.
summary: Reasons for terminating the contract.

content: The government entity may terminate the contract if the public interest so requires, or if an agreement is reached on termination with the contractor after the approval of the ministry, in accordance with the conditions and procedures explained by the regulation.
summary: Terminating the contract if the public interest so requires or by agreement with the contractor with the ministry’s approval.

content: Upon termination of the contract under paragraph (1) or paragraph (2/a) or paragraph (2/c) of Article (seventy-six) of the system, the final guarantee must be confiscated without prejudice to the right of the government entity to recourse against the contractor for compensation for any damages it has suffered, and the committee stipulated in Article (eighty-eight) of the system shall be provided with a copy of the decision; to consider preventing dealing with the contractor with the government entity.
summary: Confiscating the final guarantee in cases of contract termination with the possibility of compensation and preventing dealing.

content: The government entity shall evaluate the performance of its contractor after the completion of his execution of the contract, using a model for evaluating the performance of contractors. The results of evaluating the performance of contractors shall not be announced; until the evaluation decision is final. The regulation shall specify the controls and procedures necessary for implementing this, and the impact of weak contractor performance.
summary: Evaluating the contractor’s performance after completion of contract execution.

content: The government entity may assign what it dispenses with of movables to government entities and their affiliated entities, provided that it informs the ministry thereof. The government entity owning the movables shall, through the portal, inform government entities of the types and quantities of movables, and specify a period for them to disclose their desire for them. If they do not respond within that period, it may sell them through public auction if their estimated value is (two hundred thousand) riyals or more, after announcing it on the portal and its website; in accordance with the rules for announcing public competitions.
summary: Assigning or selling movables through public auction.

content: Movables whose estimated value is less than (two hundred thousand) riyals shall be sold; either through public auction, or by the method that the government entity deems to be in the interest of the general treasury of the state, provided that the entity provides the opportunity for the largest number of bidders.
summary: Sale of movables with a value less than two hundred thousand riyals through public auction or another method.

content: 1- If the auction is by sealed bids, the bidder shall submit an initial guarantee with his bid of (2%) of the bid value. 2- The party to whom the auction is awarded shall increase his guarantee to (5%) of the value of his bid, within (fifteen) working days from the date of the award, and if this period expires without increasing it, his initial guarantee shall not be returned to him, and the guarantee shall not be released until the full value of the movables he purchased and their transportation costs are paid, and the guarantee shall be returned to those who were not awarded the auction. 3- If the auction is public, the party to whom the auction is awarded shall submit a guarantee of (5%) of its value, and it is permissible to accept a bank check or cash amount as a guarantee in a public auction.
summary: Required guarantees in auctions.

content: If no one submits a bid after announcing it, it shall be announced again. If no one submits a bid for the second time, the competent authority has the right to invite specialists in the field of the items to be sold and offer them for sale. If they do not submit a suitable price, it may be granted to civil society organizations or any non-profit entity, provided that the ministry is informed thereof.
summary: Procedures if no bids are submitted for the auction.

content: The regulation shall specify the auction procedures and the formation of sales committees.
summary: Specifying auction procedures and committee formation in the regulation.

content: The government entity may secure some of its needs by leasing, or replacing its existing movables with new ones, in accordance with the controls determined by the regulation.
summary: Permissibility of leasing or replacing movables.

content: 1- A committee or more of specialists shall be formed by a decision of the minister, whose number shall not be less than five, specifying the chairman and deputy chairman of the committee, and the decision shall stipulate a reserve member or more. This committee shall be reconstituted every three years, and membership therein may be renewed. The minister shall issue a decision specifying the rules and procedures of the committee’s work, and shall determine the allowances of its members and secretary. 2- The committee shall be responsible for the following: a- Considering the complaints of competitors regarding the award decision or any decision or procedure taken by the government entity before the award decision. b- Considering the complaints of contractors regarding performance evaluation decisions. c- Considering requests to amend prices in accordance with the provisions of Article (sixty-eight) of the system. 3- The decisions of the committee shall be binding on the government entity. 4- The complainant shall submit a guarantee equal to half the value of the initial guarantee; which shall be returned to him if the complaint is proven valid.
summary: Formation of a committee responsible for considering complaints and its binding decisions.

content: 1- Every competitor has the right to appeal to the government entity against any decision it has taken, before the award decision, within (five) working days from the date of issuance of the decision, and he also has the right to appeal to the government entity against the award decision, during the standstill period referred to in Article (fifty-three) of the system. 2- The government entity must decide on the appeal within (fifteen) working days from the date of receipt of the appeal, and if this period elapses without a decision on the appeal, it shall be considered rejected. 3- Within (three) days from the date of notification of the decision rejecting his appeal or from the date of expiry of the period referred to in paragraph (2) of this article without a decision on his appeal; the appellant may appeal to the committee referred to in Article (eighty-six) of the system. 4- The committee referred to in Article (eighty-six) of the system shall decide on the appeals received and notify the parties concerned within (fifteen) working days from the date of their receipt. The committee may extend the period for a similar period. 5- The government entity shall not be permitted to complete the contract procedures except after taking into account the following: a- The expiry of the standstill period without any complaints being received. b- In the event of an appeal being received and accepted; the procedures taken that violate the provisions of the system shall be corrected if possible, otherwise the competition shall be canceled. If the government entity corrects the procedures it has taken that violate the provisions of the system, and this results in another bid winning; the excluded bidder must be given the opportunity to submit an appeal against this change to the government entity within a period similar to the standstill period, and the provisions of this article shall apply to his appeal. c- In the event of an appeal being received and rejected; and the period referred to in paragraph (4) of this article elapses without the committee issuing a decision on the appeal.
summary: Right to appeal and its procedures before the government entity and the competent committee.

content: 1- A committee or more of specialists shall be formed by a decision of the minister, whose number shall not be less than five, specifying the chairman and deputy chairman of the committee, and the decision shall stipulate a reserve member or more. This committee shall be reconstituted every three years, and membership therein may be renewed. The minister shall issue a decision specifying the rules and procedures of the committee’s work, and shall determine the allowances of its members and secretary. 2- This committee shall consider the violations of competitors and contractors of the provisions of the system and the contracts concluded with them. 3- Without prejudice to any penalty stipulated by any other system; the committee may issue a decision against the violator to prevent him from dealing with government entities for a period not exceeding five years, or to reduce his classification - if any - or both. 4- Instead of applying the penalty of prohibition against the violator; the committee may impose a financial penalty on him not exceeding (10%) of the total value of his bid. 5- The decisions of the committee shall be effective from the date of their issuance, unless an order is issued by the administrative court to suspend their implementation. 6- It is permissible to appeal the decisions of the committee before the administrative court, within (sixty) days from the date of knowledge of the decision. 7- A summary of the decision shall be published at the expense of the violator in a local newspaper or any other suitable means, in the following two cases: a- If the period referred to in paragraph (6) of this article elapses without the concerned party appealing to the administrative court. b- If a final judgment is issued by the administrative court upholding the committee’s decision.
summary: Formation of a committee responsible for considering violations and its authority to impose penalties.

content: Government entities may contract with each other by direct agreement, provided that they themselves execute the works or secure the purchases, and they may also represent each other in conducting contracting procedures.
summary: Permissibility of direct contracts between government entities.

content: Contracts shall be concluded with those authorized to work directly, and intermediation in contracting shall not be permitted, and the distributor or agent authorized by the original producer shall not be considered an intermediary.
summary: Prohibition of intermediation in contracting.

content: The government entity shall be obliged to use the approved models of contracts, competition documents, prior qualification documents, models for evaluating the performance of contractors, and any other document required by the nature of the work or purchases.
summary: Obligation to use approved models in contracts and documents.

content: 1- The government entity shall execute its obligations in the contract in accordance with its conditions, and if it fails to execute its obligations, the contractor may apply to the administrative court to claim compensation. 2- The government entity may, after the approval of the minister, agree to arbitration as explained in the regulation. 3- The regulation shall specify other means of resolving disputes that arise during the execution of contracts.
summary: Execution of obligations and means of resolving disputes.

content: Companies that execute works and purchases on behalf of government entities shall be obliged to apply the provisions of the system.
summary: Obligation of companies to apply the system’s provisions.

content: Any violation of any provision of the system shall subject the responsible employee to disciplinary action, in accordance with the provisions of the Employee Discipline System and the Labor System and other applicable penal provisions applicable to employees and workers, and the government entity shall have the right to file a civil lawsuit against the violator if necessary.
summary: Disciplinary action for violating employees and provisions for civil lawsuits.

content: If there is a need to exempt a provision from the provisions of the system; it shall be submitted to the Prime Minister to form a committee of no less than three members, including the minister, the chairman of the board of directors of the authority, and the head of the competent government entity to study the matter, specifying the place of exemption and its justifications and submitting what they deem appropriate to the Prime Minister for guidance as he sees fit.
summary: Procedures for exempting a provision from the system’s provisions.

content: Taking into account the provisions of related systems, the ministry shall prepare the following: 1- A regulation to organize conflicts of interest regarding the application of the provisions of the system and regulation. 2- A regulation to organize the conduct and ethics of those responsible for implementing the provisions of the system and regulation. 3- A regulation for prioritizing local content, small and medium-sized local enterprises, and companies listed on the financial market in works and purchases, in cooperation with the authority, the General Authority for Small and Medium Enterprises, and the Capital Market Authority, which shall include: a- Mechanisms for prioritizing local content and how to calculate and apply it in works and purchases, including a preferential percentage in the technical and financial evaluation of bids or a mandatory percentage of local content of the total value of the contract. b- A mechanism for prioritizing small and medium-sized local enterprises and companies listed on the financial market in works and purchases, including a preferential percentage in evaluating bids or a specific price range or a percentage of the total value of contracts. c- Penalties resulting from the non-compliance of contractors with the requirements of local content. The Council of Ministers shall issue the regulations referred to in this article within (one hundred and twenty) days, and they shall be effective from the date of the system’s commencement.
keywords: Regulation for organizing conflicts of interest
summary: The ministry’s tasks in issuing regulatory regulations.

content: The minister shall issue the regulation within (one hundred and twenty) days from the date of publication of the system in the official gazette, and it shall be effective from the date of commencement of the system.
summary: Period for issuing the regulation by the minister.

content: This system shall replace the Government Competition and Procurement System, issued by Royal Decree No. (M/58) dated 4/9/1427 AH, and shall annul any provisions that conflict with it.
summary: Annulment of the previous system and application of the current one.

content: The system shall be effective after (one hundred and twenty) days from the date of its publication in the official gazette.
summary: Date of commencement of the system.
